llm_message:
Here are the responses for each PRISMA item:

[Yes] "Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis on the Influence of Surgeon Specialization on Outcomes Following Appendicectomy in Children"

The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.  

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to determine the influence of surgeon subspecialty on outcomes following appendicectomy in children." 

The abstract provides structured background, objectives, eligibility criteria, methods, results, and conclusions.

[Yes] "An expanding body of evidence suggests that surgeon subspecialization affects outcomes; studies found that colorectal surgery subspecialization4 and orthopedic surgery subspecialization5 lead to improved results and that outcomes from a variety of cancers are improved with subspecialization."

The introduction describes the rationale in context of what is already known.

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to determine the influence of surgeon subspecialty on outcomes following appendicectomy in children."

The objectives relate to participants, interventions, outcomes, and study design.

[No]

No review protocol or registration is indicated.

[Yes] "Eligible studies were comparative and provided data on children who had appendicectomy while under the care of general or pediatric surgical teams." 

Eligibility criteria for studies and participants are described.

[Yes] "In order to identify studies and determine eligibility, 2 authors (DD and MM) independently searched Medline and EMBASE up to June 24, 2015 using the following search strategy “([paediatric surgery OR pediatric surgery OR pediatric surgeon OR paediatric surgeon] AND (appendectomy OR appendicectomy)]."

Information sources and dates of coverage are described. 

[Yes] "“([paediatric surgery OR pediatric surgery OR pediatric surgeon OR paediatric surgeon] AND (appendectomy OR appendicectomy)]"

The full search strategy for one database is provided.

[Yes] "Titles and abstracts were examined initially and then full manuscripts were obtained to finalize eligibility."

The study selection process is described.

[Yes] "Two authors (DD and DH) independently extracted data from eligible studies using an electronic spreadsheet."

Data extraction by two authors is described. 

[Yes] "Extracted data comprised details on the following variables: lead author, publication date, study design, inclusion and exclusion criteria, outcomes reported, whether there was a specified primary endpoint, main results, numbers and characteristics of patients, surgical approach, rate of negative appendiceal histology, wound infections, intra-abdominal collections, readmissions, mortality, and length of stay."

Variables extracted are listed.

[No] 

No assessment of individual study risk of bias is described.

[Yes] "Pooled risk ratios and pooled mean differences were used to evaluate the effect of treatment by general surgery units or pediatric surgery units on dichotomous and continuous outcomes, respectively."

Summary measures used are stated.

[NA]

[Yes] "The potential for publication bias was evaluated by visually inspecting funnel plots." 

Publication bias assessment is described.

[NA] 

[NA]

[Yes] "Figure 1 summarizes the results of the search."

A flow diagram depicting study selection is provided.

[Yes] "Characteristics of the 9 included studies8,11–18 are shown in Table 1 and results from the studies are provided in Table 2."

Study characteristics are presented. 

[No]

No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented.

[Yes] "Seven studies8,11–14,16,18 (62,865 children) reported on numbers of histologically negative appendicectomies."

Results for outcomes are presented for each study.

[NA]

[No] 

No additional analyses are indicated.

[Yes] "We found that children who were managed by specialized pediatric surgery teams had lower rates of negative appendicectomy although mean length of stay was longer in this group."

Main findings are summarized.

[Yes] "Regarding limitations, the main issue is the retrospective nature of most of the included studies." 

Study and outcome level limitations are discussed. 

[Yes] "We wish to encourage future research through the use of large-scale prospective multicenter registries."

Implications for future research are discussed.

[No]

No sources of funding are described.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

"Pediatric incidental appendectomy: a systematic review"
[Yes] 
"Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary.

"Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known."  
[Yes] The rationale is described in the Background section.

"Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)."
[No] The objectives do not explicitly state the PICOS.

"Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number."
[No] A review protocol is not mentioned.

"Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale."
[Yes] The Methods section specifies eligibility criteria.

"Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched."
[Yes] The information sources are described in the Methods section. 

"Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated."
[No] The full search strategy is not provided.

"State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." 
[Yes] The study selection process is described in the Methods section.

"Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
[No] The data extraction method is not described.

"List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made."
[No] The extracted variables are not explicitly listed.

"Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis."
[NA] Risk of bias assessment is not mentioned.

"State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." 
[NA] Summary measures are not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

"Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis."
[NA] Methods for combining study results are not applicable.

"Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)."
[NA] Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable. 

"Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified."
[NA] Additional analyses were not done.

"Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram."
[Yes] A flow diagram of study selection is provided.

"For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
[Yes] Study characteristics are presented in Tables 1-3. 

"Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)."
[NA] Risk of bias was not assessed.

"For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
[NA] Outcome data are not presented this way since no meta-analysis was done.

"Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."
[NA] Meta-analyses were not performed.

"Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15)."  
[NA] Assessment across studies was not done.

"Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16])."
[NA] Additional analyses were not performed.

"Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)."
[Yes] The main findings are summarized in the Conclusion section.

"Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)."
[No] Limitations are not explicitly discussed.

"Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research."
[Yes] The results are interpreted in the Conclusion section.

"Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."
[No] Sources of funding are not reported.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[Minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. No structured abstract provided. [No] 

P3. "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) is considered the criterion standard for adrenal surgery in adults [1], [2], where it is used for benign or malignant tumors." - Provides rationale in context of current knowledge. [Yes]

P4. No explicit PICOS statement provided. [No]

P5. No mention of a review protocol. [No] 

P6. "NB is the most common abdominal tumor in children, with a prevalence of 1 case per 7000 live births." - Specifies participants. [Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P7. No description of information sources. [No]

P8. No full electronic search strategy provided. [No]

P9. No description of study selection process. [No] 

P10. No description of data collection process. [No]

P11. No list of variables for which data were sought. [No]

P12. No assessment of risk of bias. [No]

P13. No summary measures stated. [NA]

P14. No description of synthesis methods. [NA]

P15. No assessment of bias across studies. [NA] 

P16. No additional analyses described. [NA]

P17. No study flow diagram. [No]

P18. No table with study characteristics. [No]

P19. No assessment of risk of bias within studies. [No]

P20. No forest plots with effect sizes. [No]

P21. No meta-analysis results. [NA]

P22. No assessment of bias across studies. [NA]

P23. No additional analysis results. [NA]

P24. "Minimally invasive adrenalectomy is superior to OA for the removal of benign adrenal diseases (benign tumors or CAH). For malignant tumors, the use of MIA should be limited to selected cases (encapsulated tumors with favorable prognostic factors or metastatic NB)." - Summarizes main findings. [Yes] 

P25. No discussion of limitations. [No]

P26. "In conclusion, MIA is promising for removal of small adrenal tumors. Long-term follow-up is required to evaluate the efficacy of MIA in neuroblastomas." - Provides interpretation and implications. [Yes]

P27. No funding sources described. [No]

llm_message:
P1.
"An updated meta-analysis of laparoscopic versus open pyeloplasty for ureteropelvic junction obstruction in children" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis. [Yes]

P2. 
"Purpose: To further explore the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction compared with open pyeloplasty (OP)." - The abstract provides structured summary including objectives. [Yes]

P3.
"Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction is one of the commonest causes of hydronephrosis in adults, especially in children. And to date, open pyeloplasty (OP) has still been the gold standard for operative manage, though minimally invasive surgeries such as laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) and robot assisted laparoscopic pyeloplasty (RALP) have increasingly been adopted in pediatric practice." - The introduction describes the rationale in context of what is already known. [Yes]

P4. 
"Purpose: To further explore the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction compared with open pyeloplasty (OP)." - The objectives state the questions addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes. [Yes]

P5.
No mention of a review protocol. [No] 

P6.
"Studies regardless of the sample size will be eligible for inclusion if they meet the following criteria: 1). comparative study; 2). compared standard LP with OP; 3). proved sufficient data on outcomes of interest; 4). procedures should perform in children (less than 18 years old)." - The eligibility criteria are specified including characteristics and report criteria. [Yes]

P7. 
"A systematic literature search of electronic databases including PUBMED, Web of science and Cochrane library was carried out between Jan. 1966 and Oct. 2014 to identify eligible studies, using the following words: “hydronephrosis OR ureteropelvic junction obstruction OR pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction OR ureteral obstruction”, “pyeloplasty”, “young OR children OR child OR kids OR pediatrics” and “laparoscopic”." - The information sources are described including databases, dates, and search terms. [Yes]

P8.
No full electronic search strategy provided for any database. [No]

P9.
No explicit statement of the process for study selection. [No]

P10.
No description of data extraction methods. [No]

P11.
"The following outcome parameters were abstracted: author, year, study design, study periods, cases of LP and OP, age periods, gender distribution, sides of obstruction and number of patients with crossing-vessel. Besides, perioperative outcomes such as operative time, length of stay and overall complication rate were also abstracted." - The data items list variables extracted. [Yes] 

P12.
No description of methods for assessing risk of bias. [No]

P13.
"WMD, OR, RD and their 95% CIs were used to estimate the difference." - The summary measures are stated (risk ratio, difference in means). [Yes]

P14. [NA]

P15. [NA] 

P16. [NA]

P17.
No flow diagram of study selection. [No]

P18. 
Table 1 presents characteristics of included studies. [Yes]

P19.
No presentation of risk of bias within studies. [No]  

P20.
Table 2 and 3 present results for outcomes. [Yes]

P21. [NA]

P22. [NA]

P23. [NA]

P24.
"Our findings of this meta-analysis revealed that LP groups were with less length of hospital stay and lower complication rate than OP groups. Considering the similar success rate of these two approaches, the laparoscopic pyeloplasty is feasibility and safety in the treatment of UPJ obstruction in children, especially in high-volume centers with experienced experts." - The discussion summarizes main findings including strength of evidence. [Yes]

P25.
"There are several limitations which should be taken into account. Firstly, only one RCT was included in this meta-analysis and most of studies were retrospective, which may lead to select bias and recall bias. More large-scaled well-designed RCT are needed to explore the feasibility and safety of LP compared with OP." - Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed. [Yes]

P26. 
"Considering the select bias and recall bias, more RCTs are required to further explore the efficiencies of LP." - Conclusions are made in context of other evidence and implications. [Yes]

P27.
No mention of sources of funding or role of funders. [No]

Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[Flexible ureteroscopy and lasertripsy (FURSL) for paediatric renal calculi: Results from a systematic review]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." - The abstract provides background, objectives, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, results, and conclusions. [Yes]

P3. "To understand the role, safety and efficacy of flexible ureterorenoscopy and lasertripsy (FURSL) for paediatric renal stones." - The rationale describes the context of what is already known. [Yes] 

P4. "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." - No explicit PICOS statement is provided. [No]

llm_message:
[Yes] 
"Open versus Laparoscopic Pyloromyotomy for Pyloric Stenosis: A Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes]  
"Objective: Aim of the study was to compare the outcomes after laparoscopic pyloromyotomy (LP) with those of open pyloromyotomy (OP) for infantile pyloric stenosis."
The abstract provides a structured summary including the objectives.

[Yes]
"Pyloromyotomy is an effective surgical intervention with rare mortality and has traditionally been performed via an open technique since the early 20th century."  
The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

[Yes]
"Given the conflicting evidence of prior studies, the aim of this meta-analysis was to systematically and quantitatively evaluate all the published randomized controlled trials comparing LP with OP for infantile pyloric stenosis."
The introduction states the objective and specifies the intervention comparison being addressed. 

[No]
No protocol or registration is indicated.

[Yes] 
"Eligible studies were those that compared LP with OP for the treatment of infants with IHPS, and only randomized controlled trials was reviewed. The included studies had to report at least one of the following outcomes: complications during and following pyloromyotomy, time to goal feeds, length of stay after surgery and operative time."
The eligibility criteria are specified.

[Yes]  
"An electronic literature search of all articles from inception to February 2009 was conducted using Medline, the Cochrane Library, SCI, EMBASE, and the Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, using the following text and keywords in combination both as MeSH terms and text words: “pyloric stenosis”, “pylorostenosis”, “pyloristenosis” and “pyloromyotomy” in combination with “laparoscop*”. The China Journal Fulltext Database (from 1994 to February 2009), Chinese biological medicine disc (from 1978 to February 2009), Chinese Scientific Journals Fulltext Database (from 1989 to February 2009) and Wanfang Database (from 1997 to February 2009) were also searched using the above terms."
The information sources are described.

[Yes]
"An electronic literature search of all articles from inception to February 2009 was conducted using Medline, the Cochrane Library, SCI, EMBASE, and the Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, using the following text and keywords in combination both as MeSH terms and text words: “pyloric stenosis”, “pylorostenosis”, “pyloristenosis” and “pyloromyotomy” in combination with “laparoscop*”. The China Journal Fulltext Database (from 1994 to February 2009), Chinese biological medicine disc (from 1978 to February 2009), Chinese Scientific Journals Fulltext Database (from 1989 to February 2009) and Wanfang Database (from 1997 to February 2009) were also searched using the above terms."
The full search strategy is presented.

[Yes]
"The literature searches yielded 461 potentially relevant articles. After a review of the titles, abstracts and removal of duplicates, 17 articles were selected for further evaluation. When inclusion criteria were applied, 3 randomized controlled trials with 492 infants were finally eligible for this study ([Fig. 1])." 
The study selection process is described.

[Yes]  
"Data were extracted by 2 independent investigators, and discrepancies were discussed to reach consensus. For each eligible study, we recorded the author, date of publication, institution, sample size, study design, patient characteristics and surgical features of the study."
The data collection process is described.

[Yes]
"The primary endpoints in this review were complications during and following pyloromyotomy, the secondary endpoints included time to goal feeds, length of stay after surgery and operative time."
The data items sought are listed.

[No]
No assessment of risk of bias in individual studies is described. 

[Yes]
"For the purpose of meta-analysis, the standard deviation (SD) of continuous variables was required."
The summary measures are stated.

[NA]
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]  
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is applicable.

[NA]
No additional analyses are reported.

[Yes] 
"The literature searches yielded 461 potentially relevant articles. After a review of the titles, abstracts and removal of duplicates, 17 articles were selected for further evaluation. When inclusion criteria were applied, 3 randomized controlled trials with 492 infants were finally eligible for this study ([Fig. 1])."
The study selection process, including numbers at each stage, is described.

[Yes]  
"Baseline characteristics of included trials are summarized in [Table 1]." 
The characteristics of the included studies are presented. 

[No]
No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented.

[Yes] 
"All 3 studies [9] [10] [13] reported complications during and following pyloromytomy." 
The results for each intervention are summarized.

[NA] 
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is applicable. 

[NA]  
No additional analyses are reported.

[Yes]
"Overall, this systematic review has shown a similar frequency of complications for LP and OP procedures. Furthermore, it also showed a trend toward shorter times for LP."
The main findings are summarized.

[Yes] 
"As with any systematic review, the limitations of this study reflect those of the individual studies. Most relied on information from databases. In this review, all trials included were obtained from online databases and no other articles were reviewed. Thus, a publication bias probably existed, although we did not assess this in detail because of the small numbers of trials that could be pooled."
Study and outcome level limitations are discussed.

[Yes]
"Overall, this systematic review has shown a similar frequency of complications for LP and OP procedures. Furthermore, it also showed a trend toward shorter times for LP. Nevertheless, the conclusions from this study remain somewhat limited due to the small sample size." 
The results are interpreted in the context of the evidence and implications for future research are discussed.

[Yes] 
"Conflict of Interest: None"
The sources of funding are reported.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

[Yes] "Surgical versus conservative management of congenital pulmonary airway malformation in children: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis comparing elective resection versus expectant management."  
The abstract provides a structured summary including the objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, methods, results, and conclusions.

[Yes] "The ideal management of infants born with asymptomatic congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM) is controversial."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in context of existing knowledge.  

[Yes] "Our objective was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis of all published literature comparing the postoperative outcomes associated with elective surgery (while asymptomatic) versus those following surgery as part of expectant management (i.e., performing surgery only upon the development of symptoms) in children born with asymptomatic CPAM lesions."
The introduction provides explicit objectives with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes.

[NA]

llm_message:
Here are the responses for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

P1. [Yes] "Primary Fascial Closure versus Staged Closure with Silo in Patients with Gastroschisis: A Meta-Analysis" The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. [Yes] "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." The abstract provides a structured summary.

P3. [Yes] "Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known." The introduction describes the rationale in context of current knowledge. 

P4. [Yes] "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." The introduction states the aim is to compare outcomes for primary fascial closure versus staged repair with a silo.

P5. [No] A protocol and registration are not mentioned.

P6. [Yes] "Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale." The methods section specifies eligibility criteria. 

P7. [Yes] "Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched." The methods describe the databases searched, search terms, and date ranges.

P8. [Yes] "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." The methods provide the full search strategy.

P9. [Yes] "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." The methods describe the study selection process. 

P10. [No] The data collection process is not described.

P11. [Yes] "List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made." The methods list the outcomes extracted.

P12. [No] Risk of bias assessment is not described. 

P13. [Yes] "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." The methods state the summary measures used.

P14. [NA] No meta-analysis synthesis is described.

P15. [NA] Assessment of bias across studies is not applicable without a meta-analysis.  

P16. [NA] No additional analyses are mentioned.

P17. [Yes] "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." The results provide a flow diagram of study selection.

P18. [Yes] "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." The results present study characteristics in a table.

P19. [No] Risk of bias within studies is not presented.

P20. [Yes] "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." The results present forest plots with effect estimates.

P21. [NA] No meta-analysis synthesis is presented.

P22. [NA] Assessment of bias across studies is not applicable without a meta-analysis.

P23. [NA] No additional analyses are presented. 

P24. [Yes] "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." The discussion summarizes the main findings.

P25. [Yes] "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." The discussion describes limitations.

P26. [Yes] "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." The discussion provides an interpretation and implications.

P27. [Yes] "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." The funding sources are described.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[Observation versus prophylactic Ladd procedure for asymptomatic intestinal rotational abnormalities in heterotaxy syndrome: A systematic review]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." - No structured abstract provided. [No]

P3. "The management of intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRA) in heterotaxy syndrome (HS) remains inconsistent. Because of the high incidence of malrotation in HS, screening of asymptomatic patients is standard of care in some institutions." - Describes rationale in context of existing knowledge. [Yes] 

P4. "Our aim was to perform a complete and thorough review of all current literature on IRA in pediatric HS patients, to report the known incidence of volvulus among infants with HS, and to report the associated Ladd operative morbidity and mortality." - Provides objectives with participants, interventions, and outcomes. [Yes]

P5. No mention of review protocol or registration. [No] 

P6. "Exclusion criteria were non-English language articles, case reports, case studies with three patients or less, and studies without outcomes data." - Specifies eligibility criteria. [Yes]

P7. "An online database search for all articles published between January 1993 and January 2014 on pediatric patients using the following keywords was performed: “heterotaxy”, “rotation”, “volvulus”, “Ladd procedure”, “Ivemark”, “asplenia”, and “polysplenia”. Searches were repeated in PubMed, Medline, CINAHL, and Cochrane library." - Describes information sources and dates of coverage. [Yes]

P8. No full electronic search strategy provided. [No]

P9. "Two independent researchers (R.L. and R.M.) performed the search, critically reviewed and extracted eligible articles. Bibliographies of identified studies were examined to identify any additional eligible studies. Duplicate listed articles were deleted. Two other independent researchers (A.A. and A.W.) confirmed the inclusion of appropriate citations based on study definitions and aims." - States process of study selection. [Yes]

P10. No description of data extraction or confirmation methods. [No] 

P11. No list of data items sought. [No]

P12. No methods for assessing risk of bias described. [No]

P13. No summary measures stated. [No] 

P14. [NA]

P15. [NA] 

P16. [NA]

P17. Figure 1 provides flow diagram of study selection. [Yes]

P18. Table 1 provides characteristics of included studies. [Yes]

P19. No assessment of risk of bias for individual studies. [No]

P20. Results summarize findings from individual studies in text and tables. [Yes]

P21. [NA]

P22. [NA]

P23. [NA]

P24. "The Ladd procedure is not without significant morbidity and mortality in heterotaxy patients. Further prospective studies should investigate predictors of mesenteric width to spare the unnecessary morbidity of surgery in patients who are at low risk for volvulus." - Summarizes main findings and implications. [Yes]

P25. "This systematic review is limited by disparities and inconsistency of data extracted from principally retrospective studies which are discussed above." - Discusses limitations. [Yes] 

P26. "A randomized, prospective trial to determine which subsets of patients with HS have the highest risk of volvulus is needed in order to optimize the care of this patient population." - Provides interpretation and implications for research. [Yes]

P27. No mention of funding sources. [No]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

[Yes] "Paediatric sutureless circumcision: a systematic literature review"

Identifies the report as a systematic review in the title.

[Yes] "We review the literature on recent advances that have been made in paediatric circumcision and the use of a sutureless technique with tissue glue for wound approximation."  

Provides background and objectives in the abstract.

[Yes] "Circumcision can be undertaken using a variety of techniques. For the technique to be successful, it should be easy to perform, avoid excessive haemorrhage and achieve a good cosmetic and functional result with minimal postoperative care. Naturally, there are differences between circumcision in the paediatric and adult populations and here we review the literature on recent advances that have been made in paediatric circumcision and the use of a sutureless technique with tissue glue for wound approximation."

Describes rationale for review in context of existing knowledge. 

[No]

Does not provide explicit PICOS statement.

[No] 

Does not indicate if a review protocol exists.

[Yes] "In the last 20 years, surgeons have become increasingly interested in the use and application of adhesive bonds [4]. Tissue adhesives have been used in a number of medical applications, including traumatic lacerations, bronchopleural fistula repair, intestinal anastomosis and middle ear surgery [5–7] and for closure of the skin wounds following herniotomy [8] and recently advances have been made in the use of tissue glue in circumcision."

Specifies study characteristics of interest - use of tissue glue in circumcision.

[Yes] "The technique of sutureless circumcision has been explained by several authors in the literature, with either a CO2 laser being used to cut the inner and outer layer of the prepuce [2] or a scalpel for the outer layer followed by bipolar diathermy scissors on the inner layer to achieve haemostasis [2]."

Describes information sources searched - literature/previous publications. 

[No]

Does not provide full search strategy.

[Yes] "The technique of sutureless circumcision has been explained by several authors in the literature, with either a CO2 laser being used to cut the inner and outer layer of the prepuce [2] or a scalpel for the outer layer followed by bipolar diathermy scissors on the inner layer to achieve haemostasis [2]."

States that relevant literature was reviewed.

[Yes] "The technique of sutureless circumcision has been explained by several authors in the literature, with either a CO2 laser being used to cut the inner and outer layer of the prepuce [2] or a scalpel for the outer layer followed by bipolar diathermy scissors on the inner layer to achieve haemostasis [2]."  

Implies data was extracted from literature.

[Yes] "Tissue glues have been used in a number of medical applications, including traumatic lacerations, bronchopleural fistula repair, intestinal anastomosis and middle ear surgery [5–7] and for closure of the skin wounds following herniotomy [8] and recently advances have been made in the use of tissue glue in circumcision."

Specifies interventions of interest - tissue glues.

[NA]

 Does not assess risk of bias in individual studies.

[NA] 

Does not provide summary measures.

[NA]

Does not combine results quantitatively.

[NA]

No assessment of bias across studies. 

[NA]

No additional analyses performed.

[No] 

Does not provide study flow diagram.

[Yes] "In 2001, Subramaniam and Jacobsen looked at the advantages of tissue glue versus sutures for circumcision in children. They conducted a prospective randomised controlled study over a period of 3 months in 2001 and recruited 152 boys. Glue was used in 80 and sutures in 72 boys undergoing circumcision. There were a total of four postoperative complications including three patients with bleeding and one case of infection."

Provides summary characteristics of included studies.

[NA] 

Does not assess risk of bias in individual studies.

[Yes] "In 2001, Subramaniam and Jacobsen looked at the advantages of tissue glue versus sutures for circumcision in children. They conducted a prospective randomised controlled study over a period of 3 months in 2001 and recruited 152 boys. Glue was used in 80 and sutures in 72 boys undergoing circumcision. There were a total of four postoperative complications including three patients with bleeding and one case of infection."

Presents results for main outcomes.

[NA]

Does not provide quantitative synthesis. 

[NA]

No assessment of bias across studies.

[NA] 

No additional analyses.

[Yes] "In conclusion, sutureless circumcision in children appears to have significant advantages to the standard closure using interrupted sutures. As reported there are advantages that include a better postoperative appearance and parental satisfaction, reduced inflammation and infection rates and a reduced operative time."

Summarizes main findings.

[Yes] "The disadvantage is in the adolescent age group where tissue glue alone may not be an adequate form of closure due to the increased tension placed on the wound should the boys develop an erection. There is also a learning curve associated with the application of glue, but with experience a reproducible and reliable outcome should be expected."

Discusses limitations around age groups and application of glue.

[Yes] "In conclusion, sutureless circumcision in children appears to have significant advantages to the standard closure using interrupted sutures. As reported there are advantages that include a better postoperative appearance and parental satisfaction, reduced inflammation and infection rates and a reduced operative time."

Provides general interpretation of results.

[No] 

Does not describe sources of funding.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes, explanations, and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[Neonatal] Endosurgical Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia Repair: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis. [Yes]

P2. "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
No structured abstract provided. [No]  

P3. "CDH is a common birth defect in neonatology and pediatric surgical practice. In the context of persistently high morbidity and mortality, varied pre- and postnatal surgical strategies have been tried with limited success."
The introduction provides context and rationale. [Yes]

P4. "We have therefore asked whether MIS approaches to neonatal CDH repair are associated with changes in survival, CDH recurrence risk, operative time, and/or prosthetic patch usage." 
The objectives relate to participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes. [Yes]

P5. No mention of a review protocol. [No] 

P6. "Studies were eligible for inclusion in the review and meta-analysis if they directly compared open and endosurgical CDH repair in the newborn infant and included outcome data regarding survival, CDH recurrence, prosthetic patch use, and operative time."
Eligibility criteria for studies are provided. [Yes]

P7. "MEDLINE (1950 to present), Embase (1980 to present) and Cochrane Controlled Trials Register databases were searched...The date of the last electronic search was 1st October 2009."
Information sources and dates searched are described. [Yes]

P8. No full search strategy provided. [No]

P9. "Two independent reviewers reviewed all studies in abstract form. Exclusions were only made at this point if it was absolutely clear that the above criteria were met. Full-text versions of the remaining studies were retrieved and corresponding authors were contacted for further information if necessary." 
The study selection process is described. [Yes]

P10. No mention of data extraction process. [No] 

P11. "The following demographic data was sought for each group: proportion of male sex, proportion with left-sided CDH, mean birth weight, mean gestational age, APGAR score at 1 minute, proportion requiring ECMO, and proportion with significant associated anomalies."
Data items sought are listed. [Yes]

P12. No mention of risk of bias assessment. [No]

P13. "Weighted treatment effect was calculated using the fixed effects model. Treatment effect sizes were calculated and presented as relative risk (RR) for dichotomous variables and weighted mean difference (WMD) for continuous variables"
Summary measures are stated. [Yes] 

P14. "Data meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan) Version 5.0 (The Nordic Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, 2008). Weighted treatment effect was calculated using the fixed effects model."
Methods for combining study results are described. [Yes]

P15. No assessment of risk of bias across studies mentioned. [NA]

P16. No additional analyses mentioned. [NA]

P17. "The electronic search identified a total of 292 studies. Exclusions were made as detailed in the flow chart (Fig. 2)."
A study flow diagram is provided. [Yes]

P18. "Analyzing the demographic data in each study, there were no statistically significant differences in proportion of male sex, mean birth weight, proportion of left sided CDH, or proportion of cases with significant associated anomalies between open and endosurgical groups." 
Study characteristics are presented. [Yes]

P19. No assessment of risk of bias within studies presented. [No] 

P20. "Results from the individual studies for the primary and secondary outcome measures are included in forest plots (Fig. 3)."
Results for each study are presented in forest plots. [Yes]

P21. "Meta-analysis reveals that recurrence was higher (RR: 3.21 [1.11, 9.29], P = 0.03) and operative time was longer (WMD: 50.38 minutes [31.79, 68.97], P < 0.00001) in the endosurgical group." 
Results of the meta-analyses are presented. [Yes]

P22. No assessment of bias across studies presented. [NA]

P23. No additional analyses presented. [NA]

P24. "This meta-analysis of methodologically limited comparative studies indicates neonatal thoracoscopic CDH repair has increased recurrence risk and operative time compared with open repair: although survival and patch usage appear comparable, such similarities may be subject to type 2 error as well as biases."
A summary of the evidence is provided. [Yes]

P25. "However, these findings need to be considered in the context of the methodological limitations of the studies available for inclusion; for each outcome measure, we will discuss the potential for bias and other confounding factors."
Study limitations are discussed. [Yes] 

P26. "Better quality evidence is therefore required. Systematic reviews and meta-analyses frequently conclude with calls for more randomized controlled trials (RCTs). In contrast, we call for prospective, comprehensive, multi-institutional registry data on neonatal endosurgical CDH repair."
Conclusions and implications are discussed. [Yes]

P27. No funding sources reported. [No]

llm_message:
[Yes] "Laparoscopic portoenterostomy versus open portoenterostomy for the treatment of biliary atresia: a systematic review and meta-analysis of comparative studies"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "Background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
The abstract provides a structured summary including all applicable elements.

[Yes] "Biliary atresia (BA) is one of the most common reasons for portoenterostomy in pediatric surgery, which is characterized by progressive inflammatory disease of the hepatobiliary system that occurs in about 1/9,000–1/15,000 neonates [1]."

[Yes] "Complete Versus Partial Fundoplication in Children with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease: Results of a Systematic Review and Meta-analysis"

[Yes] "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."

[Yes] "Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known." 

[NA] "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)."

[Yes] "Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number."

[Yes] "Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale."

[Yes] "Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched."

[Yes] "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated."

[Yes] "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." 

[Yes] "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."

[Yes] "List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made."

[Yes] "Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis."

[Yes] "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)."

[Yes] "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis."

[Yes] "Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)."

[NA] "Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified."

[Yes] "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram."

[Yes] "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."

[Yes] "Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)."

[Yes] "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."

[Yes] "Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."

[Yes] "Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15)." 

[NA] "Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16])."

[Yes] "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)."

[Yes] "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)."

[Yes] "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research."

[Yes] "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."

The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] 
"A systematic review and meta-analysis is reported to address robust evidence for curative “gross total tumor resection” (GTR) in Stage 3 and Stage 4 neuroblastoma."

The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, eligibility criteria, methods, results, and conclusions.

[Yes]
"Neuroblastoma is a challenging disease for pediatric cancer specialists and surgeons. Survival remains poor with greater than 50% of children having widespread metastatic disease at initial clinical presentation."  

The introduction describes the rationale for the review in context of current knowledge.

[Yes]
"We sought to include randomized controlled trials (if available) and observational studies."

The objectives mention the participants, interventions, outcomes, and study designs of interest.

[No]

No protocol or registration is mentioned.

[Yes] 
"Studies were included if they reported 5-year survival data for children under 18 years of age with stages 3 and/or 4 neuroblastoma following gross total resection and subtotal resection (STR)."

Eligibility criteria are specified including participants, interventions, and outcomes.

[Yes]
"The following databases were included in the search - Medline, Embase and Cochrane."

Information sources including databases and dates are described. 

[Yes]
"Search terms used were: (Neuroblastoma) AND (Surgery OR (gross AND total AND resection) OR (limited AND resection))."

The full search strategy is presented for at least one database.

[Yes]
"Studies were reviewed by PJF and DM independently." 

The study selection process is described.

[Yes] 
"Data were extracted using a custom designed proforma before commencement of the search strategy for first author, publication date, study center institution, time period of study, participant age range, chemotherapy regime, MYCN status, stage, 3 and stage 4 sample size defined by INSS, number of GTR and STR operations performed, 5-year overall survival (OS), 5-year disease free survival, and reported surgical complications."

Data collection using piloted forms is described. 

[Yes]
"Data were extracted [...] for first author, publication date, study center institution, time period of study, participant age range, chemotherapy regime, MYCN status, stage, 3 and stage 4 sample size defined by INSS, number of GTR and STR operations performed, 5-year overall survival (OS), 5-year disease free survival, and reported surgical complications."

Variables extracted are listed including participants, interventions, outcomes, and study details.

[No]

Individual study risk of bias is not described.

[Yes]
"Odds ratios (OR) were calculated with 95% confidence intervals (CI) using Mantel–Haenszel calculations and a random effects model, and summary odds ratio for 5-year survival outcomes."

Principal summary measures are stated.

[NA]

This is not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed for stage 3 neuroblastoma.

[NA]

Assessment of publication bias is not applicable without a meta-analysis. 

[NA] 

No additional analyses are described.

[Yes]
"A flow chart of the study selection process is outlined in Figure 1."

The study selection process is shown in a flow diagram with exclusions at each stage.

[Yes]
"All 15 studies included in the analysis were case series [Citation4–7, Citation14–24, Citation58]." 

Study characteristics are presented with citations.

[No]

Individual study risk of bias is not presented.

[NA]

Results of individual studies are not applicable for a systematic review without a meta-analysis.

[NA] 

Results of meta-analyses are not applicable as none were done for stage 3.

[NA]

Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable without a meta-analysis.

[NA]

No additional analyses are described. 

[Yes]
"Findings strongly showed that there was a significantly improved 5 year survival achieved following GTR in stage 3 neuroblastoma."

The main findings and strength of evidence are summarized.

[Yes] 
"Although the inclusion of such studies may reduce concerns about publication bias (as the decision to publish was unrelated to the outcome with respect to the surgical procedure) the findings nonetheless highlight the few reports in the neuroblastoma literature that have specifically examined survival outcome metrics following GTR or STR."

Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.

[Yes] 
"We believe a prospective well-designed randomized trial incorporating patient age, tumor site and elements of tumor biology (MYCN, DNA ploidy status, etc.) is needed to fully address the role of surgery in stage 4 neuroblastoma." 

Conclusions and implications for future research are provided.

[No]

No sources of funding are described.

llm_message:
P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both. 

"Interventions for primary vesicoureteric reflux"

The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.

The abstract provides a structured summary with background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal methods, results, limitations, and conclusions. 

[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

"Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) results in urine passing retrograde up the ureter. Urinary tract infections (UTI) associated with VUR have been considered a cause of permanent renal parenchymal damage in children with VUR."

The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about VUR and its association with UTI and renal damage.

[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

"The aim of this review was to evaluate the available evidence for both benefits and harms of the currently available treatment options for primary VUR: operative, non-operative or no intervention."

The objectives are stated with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes. 

[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.

No mention of a review protocol.

[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.

The methods section specifies eligibility criteria including study design, participants, interventions, and outcomes. Rationale is provided. No restrictions on language or publication status.

[Yes] 

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched. 

The sources of information are described including databases searched with dates, conference proceedings, reference lists, authors contacted, and date last searched.

[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

The full search strategy for one database is provided in the appendix.

[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).

The process for study selection, including initial screening, assessment of eligibility, and inclusion is described.

[Yes] 

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

The data extraction process is described, including use of a standardized form, completion by at least two authors independently, and contacting authors for additional data as needed.

[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.

The outcomes for which data were extracted are listed and defined in the criteria for considering studies section. No other variables are mentioned.

[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.

The risk of bias assessment method is described including the domains assessed and that it was done at the study level. Its use in data synthesis is not specified. 

[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

The principal summary measures are stated as risk ratio and mean difference.

[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.

[NA]

P15. Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).  

[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.

Planned sensitivity analysis based on study quality and subgroup analysis are described.

[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included is provided with reasons for exclusions and a flow diagram. 

[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.

Study characteristics including sample size, participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and follow-up periods are presented in text and tables for each included study.

[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).

The risk of bias assessment for each study is presented in text, figures, and a summary table. Outcome level assessment is not mentioned.

[Yes] 

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.

For relevant outcomes, results are presented in text and analyzed with summary estimates and confidence intervals in forest plots.

[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.

[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15). 

[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).

[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).

The main findings are summarized including strength of evidence. Relevance to healthcare providers is considered.

[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).

Limitations are discussed at the study, outcome, and review levels.

[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

General conclusions are made in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research are discussed.

[Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.

Sources of funding and other support are described; no role of funders is mentioned.

[Yes]

Here are the assessments for the PRISMA items:

1. "Hepaticoduodenostomy versus hepaticojejunostomy after resection of choledochal cyst: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
[Yes] The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

2. "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary with background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, synthesis methods, results, conclusions.

3. "Excision has been established as a standard management practice for choledochal cysts in the last few decades." 
[Yes] The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of current knowledge.

4. "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)."
[No] The introduction does not provide an explicit PICOS statement.

5. "Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number."
[No] The methods do not indicate if a review protocol exists or is registered.

6. "Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale."
[Yes] The eligibility criteria specify study and report characteristics including follow-up period, language, and publication status. 

7. "Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched."
[Yes] The information sources section describes the databases searched with coverage dates and the last date searched.

8. "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." 
[No] The search strategy is not provided.

9. "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
[Yes] The study selection process including screening, eligibility assessment, and inclusion is described.

10. "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
[Yes] The data collection process describes data extraction by independent reviewers. 

11. "List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made."
[Yes] The data items section lists the variables extracted.

12. "[NA]" There is no assessment of individual study bias.

13. "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)."
[Yes] The analysis methods state the summary measures used including odds ratios and mean differences.

14. "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." 
[Yes] The synthesis methods describe pooling data using fixed and random effects models and assessing heterogeneity with I2.

15. "[NA]" No assessment of publication bias is mentioned.

16. "[NA]" No additional analyses are reported. 

17. "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram."
[No] The number of studies screened, assessed, and included is provided but without a flow diagram.

18. "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
[Yes] A table summarizes the characteristics of the included studies.

19. "[NA]" Individual study bias is not assessed.

20. "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
[Yes] For each outcome, data for each intervention and group comparisons with forest plots are presented.

21. "Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."
[Yes] The results present meta-analysis findings with confidence intervals and heterogeneity measures.

22. "[NA]" Publication bias is not assessed.

23. "[NA]" No additional analyses were performed.

24. "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)."
[Yes] The discussion summarizes the main findings and considers their relevance.

25. "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)."
[Yes] The limitations section discusses limitations at the study and review levels.

26. "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research."
[Yes] The conclusion interprets the results in the context of other evidence and suggests future research.

27. "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."
[No] Sources of funding and support are not described.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for the 27 PRISMA items:

[Yes] "Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Focusing on Major Complications"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
The abstract provides a structured summary covering all applicable elements.

[Yes] "The surgical treatment of choice in the last century has been the longitudinal splitting of the seromuscular layer of the pylorus without suturing, which is defined as “pyloromyotomy.” The constriction is relieved and allows normal passage of stomach contents into the duodenum." 
The introduction describes the rationale in context of existing knowledge.

[Yes] "Therefore, the aim of this study was to compare the results of LP and open pyloromyotomy (OP) by means of a systematic review of the available randomized trials while focusing on major complications (i.e., incomplete pyloromyotomy, perforation, and need for re-operation)."
The objectives explicitly state the focus on major complications. 

[NA]
A review protocol is not mentioned.

[Yes] "Studies were included in the review if they were RCTs that compared the results of LP and OP in children with HPS with admission time after pyloromyotomy and postoperative complication rate as outcomes."
Study eligibility criteria are specified.

[Yes] "Retrieval of studies was performed through a systematic search of the databases PubMed, Ovid (Ovid Technologies, New York, NY) and Cochrane (Cochrane database of systematic reviews)." 
Databases searched are described.

[Yes] "Keywords and medical subject heading (MeSH) terms used were “pyloric stenosis,” “pyloromyotomy,” “comparative studies,” “open,” “laparoscopic,” and “postoperative complications.”"
Full search strategy is presented for at least one database.

[Yes] "Potentially eligible studies were reviewed independently by two authors (MWNO, RB) for inclusion and exclusion criteria."
Study selection process is described.

[Yes] "From the included studies, data on setting, methodological quality [according to the Cochrane handbook for systematic reviews of interventions (http://dcc.cochrane.org/sites/dcc.cochrane.org/files/uploads/RCT)], population, and type of surgery were extracted by two authors independently, as well as data on primary and secondary outcome measures."
Data collection process is described.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[The management of newborns with esophageal atresia and right aortic arch: A systematic review or still unsolved problem]"
[Yes] Identifies as a systematic review in title.

P2. [NA] No abstract provided.

P3. "This study provides a systematic review of epidemiology, diagnosis, management and short-term results of children with EA and RAA."  
[Yes] Describes rationale for review.

P4. "Aim of the study: The management of newborns with esophageal atresia (EA) and right aortic arch (RAA) is still an unsolved problem."
[Yes] Specifies participants, condition, and aim. 

P5. [No] Does not mention protocol or registration.

P6. "Inclusion criteria were English language articles reporting original data on epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment of newborns with EA."
[Yes] Specifies eligibility criteria.

P7. "The PubMed database was searched for original studies on children with EA and RAA." 
[Yes] Specifies information sources.

P8. [No] Does not provide full search strategy.

P9. "The full text of the selected articles was examined."
[Yes] States process for study selection.

P10. "In each study, data were extracted for the following outcomes: number of patients, associated anomalies, type of surgical repair, morbidity and mortality rate."
[Yes] Describes data collection process.

P11. "For each study, data were extracted for the following outcomes: overall number of patients, associated cardiovascular anomalies, type of surgical repair, morbidity and mortality rate."
[Yes] Lists variables extracted.

P12. [No] Does not describe risk of bias assessment. 

P13. [No] Does not state summary measures.

P14. [NA] No quantitative synthesis performed.

P15. [NA] No assessment of bias across studies.

P16. [NA] No additional analyses reported.

P17. "Eight studies were selected, including 54 patients with EA and RAA." 
[Yes] Reports numbers of studies screened and included.

P18. "All were single-institution, retrospective studies, case reports or case series."
[Yes] Describes characteristics of included studies. 

P19. [No] Does not assess risk of bias within studies.

P20. "In these patients, primary anastomosis was achieved through the right approach in 3 (thoracotomy in 2 and thoracoscopy in 1) while the left approach was the primary choice in 4 (thoracotomy in 2 and thoracoscopy in 2)."
[Yes] Presents results for each study.

P21. [NA] No quantitative synthesis performed.

P22. [NA] No assessment of bias across studies.

P23. [NA] No additional analyses presented.

P24. "A multicenter, prospective randomized study is strongly required."
[Yes] Provides interpretation of results.

P25. "This systematic review had some inherent limitations." 
[Yes] Discusses limitations.

P26. "A multicenter prospective study comparing RT and LT in infants with EA and RAA is strongly required."
[Yes] Provides conclusions.

P27. [No] Does not describe sources of funding.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

P1. "[Cervical/thoracotomic/thoracoscopic approaches for H-type congenital tracheo-esophageal fistula: A systematic review]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." - The abstract provides a structured summary. [Yes] 

P3. "Aim of this systematic review is to investigate the thoracic and cervical surgical approaches of H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) according to the position of the fistula." - The rationale for the review is described. [Yes]

P4. "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." - No explicit PICOS statement is provided. [No]

P5. "Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number." - No review protocol is mentioned. [No] 

P6. "Eligible study designs were cohort, case report, case series and review." - Study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified. [Yes]

P7. "The PubMed database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) was searched for studies on treatment of H-type TEF that were published since January 1977." - The information source and date last searched are described. [Yes]

P8. "The following keywords were searched individually or in association: isolated trachea-esophageal fistula, H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, N-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, cervicotomy, thoracoscopy and thoracotomy." - The full search strategy is not provided. [No]

P9. "Titles and abstracts of identified publications were checked and reviewed against the predefined inclusion criteria, and afterward, the full text the articles were similarly assessed for eligibility." - The study selection process is described. [Yes] 

P10. "Two independent authors extracted information related to the study." - The data collection process is described. [Yes] 

P11. "For each study, data were extracted for three primary outcomes and many secondary outcomes." - The variables extracted are listed. [Yes]

P12. "Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales." - Methods for assessing risk of bias are described. [Yes] 

P13. "The principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means) are not applicable for this systematic review without meta-analysis. [NA]

P14. "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." Not applicable, as no meta-analysis was performed. [NA]

P15. "Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)." Not assessed. [NA]

P16. "Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified." No additional analyses mentioned. [NA]

P17. "The study selection process is presented in Fig. 1." - A flow diagram of study selection is provided. [Yes]

P18. "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." - Study characteristics and citations are provided in tables. [Yes]

P19. "Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales." - Individual study risk of bias is assessed. [Yes]

P20. "For the thoracoscopic group all the five eligible studies included the primary outcome." - Results for each study are presented. [Yes]

P21. Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed. [NA]

P22. Not assessed. [NA] 

P23. No additional analyses mentioned. [NA]

P24. "The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type fistula in children is poor and the skills and preferences of the surgeons guide the choice of the procedure." - A summary of evidence is provided. [Yes]

P25. "This systematic review had some inherent limitations." - Study and review limitations are discussed. [Yes]

P26. "Further well-designed, prospective studies which take into account selection and performance bias, and the issue of confounding are strongly required." - Implications for future research are described. [Yes]

P27. "The authors have no financial relationships relevant to this article to disclose." - Sources of funding are reported. [Yes]
