llm_message:
Here is the assessment for the 27 PRISMA items based on the provided full text:

P1. "[Morbidity and mortality in total esophagogastric dissociation: A systematic review☆]" - Identifies as a systematic review in title. [Yes]

P2. "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." - Provides structured abstract with background, objectives, methods, results and conclusions. [Yes]

P3. "Background/Purpose: Total esophagogastric dissociation has been described as both a primary and a rescue procedure for patients with severe gastroesophageal reflux." - Describes rationale and context. [Yes] 

P4. "Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." - Does not provide explicit PICOS statement. [No]

P5. "Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number." - Does not mention protocol or registration. [No]

P6. "Methods: Series were updated where possible by personal communication with the author. Patient characteristics, indications, morbidity, and mortality were analyzed." - Specifies criteria for eligibility. [Yes]

P7. "Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched." - Describes information sources including databases, personal communication, and institutional data. [Yes]

P8. "Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." - Does not provide full search strategy. [No]  

P9. "Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." - Does not describe screening or selection process. [No]

P10. "Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators." - Does not describe data extraction or collection process. [No] 

P11. "Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made." - Specifies data items as patient characteristics, indications, morbidity and mortality. [Yes]

P12. "Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis." - Does not assess risk of bias. [No]

P13. "Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." - Does not state summary measures. [No]

P14. "Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." - Does not perform meta-analysis. [NA]

P15. "Methdos / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)." - Does not assess risk of bias across studies. [No] 

P16. "Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified." - Does not perform additional analyses. [NA]

P17. "Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." - Gives number of studies included but not screened or assessed, no flow diagram. [No]

P18. "Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." - Presents some characteristics like number of patients and citations. [Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P19. "Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)." - Does not present risk of bias. [No]

P20. "Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." - Presents summary data but not effect estimates or forest plots. [Partial Yes <added>[Yes]</added>]

P21. "Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency." - Does not perform meta-analysis. [NA] 

P22. "Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15)." - Does not assess risk of bias across studies. [No]

P23. "Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16])." - Does not perform additional analyses. [NA]

P24. "Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." - Summarizes main findings and compares to other evidence. [Yes]

P25. "Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." - Does not discuss limitations. [No]

P26. "Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." - Provides interpretation and implications. [Yes]

P27. "Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." - Does not describe funding or support. [No]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

"What is the best prosthetic material for patch repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? Comparison and meta-analysis of porcine small intestinal submucosa and polytetrafluoroethylene" [Yes]
Title identifies the report as a systematic review comparing two prosthetic materials.

"Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." [No] 
The abstract does not contain all elements of a structured summary.

"Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known." [Yes]
"Larger defects of the diaphragm in patients with CDH have been associated with more severe pulmonary hypoplasia and poorer survival [1]; the past 2 decades have witnessed an improvement in medical management of patients with CDH with the use of gentle ventilation and delayed surgical repair, thus leading to improved survival rates in many centers [2]. Concomitantly, there has been a rise in the incidence of patch repairs [3], [11] and also increased long-term morbidity [4]."
Provides context and rationale.

"Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." [Yes] 
"The aim of our study was to compare recurrence, small bowel obstruction (SBO), and mortality rates for CDH repair between an absorbable (Surgisis [SIS]; Cook Biotech, Inc, West Lafayette, IN) and a nonabsorbable polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) (Gore-Tex; W.L. Gore & Associates, Inc, Neward, DE) material at our institution."
States aim to compare two interventions for three outcomes.

"[NA]"
No protocol or registration mentioned.

"Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale." [Yes]
"To be selected, a study had to evaluate an absorbable (SIS) and a nonabsorbable (PTFE) material for CDH patch repair and provide relevant and interpretable data."
Specifies intervention comparison and outcome eligibility criteria.

"Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched." [Yes]
"All publications describing both absorbable (SIS) and nonabsorbable (PTFE) material for treatment of CDH were sought from the Cochrane Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) database. All studies were identified through electronic searches of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), EMBASE (1980 onwards), and CINAHL (1982 onwards) and from hand-searching journals and conference proceedings."
Lists databases searched without date ranges.

"Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." [No]
No search strategy provided.

"State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." [Yes]
"Three authors (RR, AN, and JL) independently assessed all published articles and identified as potentially relevant by the literature search for inclusion in the review." 
Describes process of study screening and selection.

"[NA]"
No data collection process described.

"List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made." [No]
No listing of data items sought.

"[NA]" 
No assessment of individual study bias mentioned.

"[NA]"
No summary measures described, as no meta-analysis performed.

"[NA]"
No synthesis methods described. 

"[NA]"
No assessment of publication bias mentioned.

"[NA]"
No additional analyses mentioned.

"Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." [No]
No flow diagram or details of screening and selection process provided.

"For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." [No]
No table of study characteristics provided.

"[NA]"
No assessment of individual study bias presented.

"For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." [Yes]
"Meta-analysis was performed combining our data with the data from this study (Fig. 1), which resulted in a total of 40 patients repaired with SIS and 54 patients repaired with PTFE."

"[NA]" 
No meta-analysis results presented.

"[NA]"
No assessment of publication bias presented. 

"[NA]"
No additional analyses presented.

"Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." [Yes]
"Our data further support the concept that there is no ideal prosthetic material for patch repair of CDH. Surgisis and PTFE had similarly high complication rates in terms of recurrence, SBO, and mortality. The meta-analysis performed further supported the lack of difference in these outcomes between absorbable and nonabsorbable materials."
Summarizes main findings.

"Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." [No]
No limitations discussed.

"Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." [Yes] 
"It is possible that development of new absorbable materials, which become replaced with scar tissue more quickly, or further development of composite patches will improve the recurrence risk for patch repair of CDH."
Discusses implications for future research.

"Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." [No]
No funding sources reported.

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature comparing use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies."
Title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature comparing the use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies."  
The abstract provides a structured summary including the review objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, methods, and main results.

[Yes] "The pre-formed silo (PFS) is increasingly used in the management of gastroschisis, but its benefits remain unclear."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of existing knowledge.

[Yes] "The aim of this study was to evaluate current evidence comparing the use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies in infants with gastroschisis."
The introduction explicitly states the objectives, referring to participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes. 

[No]
No mention of a review protocol.

[Yes] "Studies were selected for inclusion in the review if they reported comparative outcomes between infants treated with a PFS and infants treated with an alternate treatment strategy."
The methods section specifies the eligibility criteria including participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes.

[Yes] "We searched Medline, Embase and the Cochrane controlled trials register from inception to July 2014 using the terms ‘gastroschisis’, ‘gastroschisis and silo’, ‘preformed silo’ and ‘silastic silo’." 
The methods section describes the information sources searched including databases and dates.

[No]
The full search strategy for at least one database is not presented.

[Yes] "The literature search, assessment for inclusion and data extraction were performed independently by three reviewers and disagreements resolved by consensus."
The methods section describes the study selection process including screening and eligibility assessment.

[Yes] "Data were extracted and entered into Review Manager (v5.1, The Cochrane Collaboration) and meta-analysis was performed using a random effects model due to variation in study design and reporting."
The methods section describes the data collection process including data extraction and confirmation.

[Yes] "All outcomes were selected a priori. The primary outcome measure was time on a ventilator. Secondary outcomes were number of infants never ventilated, time on parenteral nutrition (PN), time to achieve full enteral feeds, length of hospital stay, incidence of necrotising enterocolitis, number of unplanned re-operations, infectious complications, mortality and occurrence of ventral hernia following repair."
The methods section lists the variables, outcomes, and other data items collected. 

[NA]
No assessment of individual study risk of bias is described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA] 
No summary measures are stated since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No synthesis methods are described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No additional analyses are described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[Yes] "One-thousand five-hundred and sixty-seven articles were identified using the specified search criteria and their abstracts reviewed. Following application against our inclusion criteria, 1440 were excluded on the basis of their abstract alone and the full text of 127 publications was scrutinised. One hundred and seven of these were subsequently excluded as they did not report a comparative group, did not use a PFS, or did not report outcomes from a group all treated with a PFS. Two further reports were excluded to avoid duplication of patients."
The results section describes the study selection process including numbers screened, assessed, and included, with reasons for exclusions.

[Yes] Table 1 presents the characteristics of the included studies.

[NA]
No assessment of individual study risk of bias is presented since no meta-analysis was performed. 

[NA]
No results of individual studies are presented since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]  
No results of meta-analyses are presented since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is presented since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No results of additional analyses are presented since no meta-analysis was performed.  

[Yes] "This systematic review aimed to determine comparative outcomes for infants with gastroschisis treated with either a PFS or alternate treatment strategy."
The discussion summarizes the main findings and considers their relevance.

[Yes] "The quality of evidence comparing PFS with alternate treatment strategies for gastroschisis is poor." "As a result there is significant potential for both treatment and selection biases to influence the findings of this analysis."
The discussion describes limitations at the study and outcome level.

[Yes] "Further investigation is required to identify not only the optimal treatment pathway for infants with gastroschisis which will likely include a case by case decision algorithm, but also the tools by which to measure success." 
The conclusion provides a general interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

[Yes] "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."
The funding sources are described.

llm_message:
Here are my responses for each PRISMA item:

[Yes] "Systematic review and meta-analysis of enterocolitis after one-stage transanal pull-through procedure for Hirschsprung’s disease"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "The reported incidence of post pull-through HAEC ranges from 4.6 to 54% in various series... In the present review, postoperative HAEC occurred in 92 patients, which lead to an incidence rate of HAEC of 10.2%."
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, results, and conclusions. 

[Yes] "Hirschsprung’s disease associated with enterocolitis is the most serious and potentially life-threatening complication of HD, with significant morbidity and mortality [16, 29, 30]."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

[Yes] "This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."  
The introduction provides an explicit statement of the objective to evaluate the postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT.

[No]
No review protocol or registration is indicated.

[Yes] "Detailed information was recorded regarding the type of study, patient’s age and gender, intraoperative details, and postoperative complications with particular emphasis on the incidence and outcome of HAEC."
The eligibility criteria specify that studies reporting TERPT procedures without additional laparotomy, laparoscopy or preoperative colostomy were included, with emphasis on postoperative HAEC.

[Yes] "PubMed and Medline were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients who had undergone surgical correction of HD on transanal one-stage pull-through operation between 1998 and 2009."
The information sources including PubMed and Medline databases are described. 

[No]
No full electronic search strategy is presented.

[Yes] "Out of these 54 articles, 27 articles, identified as reporting entirely TERPT without additional laparotomy, laparoscopy or preoperative colostomy, formed the basis of our study (Table 1)." 
The process for study selection is described.

[No] 
No data collection process is described. 

[Yes] "Detailed information was recorded regarding the type of study, patient’s age and gender, intraoperative details, and postoperative complications with particular emphasis on the incidence and outcome of HAEC."
The data items recorded are listed, including patient demographics, surgical details, and postoperative complications with emphasis on HAEC.

[No]
No methods for assessing risk of bias are described.

[NA]

[NA] 

[NA]

[Yes] "There were a total of 899 patients. Information about patient’s gender was reported in 760 (84.5%) patients. 563 (74.1%) patients were male and 197 (25.9%) patients were female. A male-to-female ratio of 2.8:1 was observed." 
The number of studies screened and included is provided in a flow diagram and characteristics like sample size and gender are presented.

[Yes] "Postoperative complications occurred in 370 (41.2%). One hundred and eighty-five of the 370 patients had minor complications, such as perianal excoriation, constipation and increased stool frequency and 188 patients had major complications such as anastomotic strictures, which were reported in 72 (8%) of the patients and required anal dilatation."
Complications for each study are presented.

[No]
No assessment of risk of bias is presented. 

[Yes] "Postoperative HAEC occurred in 92 patients (10.2%), with an early onset of 2 weeks after surgery up to 18 months. Recurrent episodes of HAEC were reported in 18 patients (2%)."
Simple summary data and effect estimates for the main outcome of HAEC are presented.

[NA]

[NA]

[NA]

[NA] 

[Yes] "This systematic review reveals that the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC after TERPT procedure is remarkably lower than incidence rates of HAEC reported after other procedures, confirming TERPT as a safe operation with a low incidence of postoperative HAEC."
The main findings are summarized, including the low incidence of postoperative HAEC with TERPT compared to other procedures.

[Yes] "However, the data are not consistent for other suggested predictive risk factors, such as type of repair."
Limitations at the study level such as inconsistent data for risk factors are discussed.

[Yes] "Preventive measures and better treatment modalities will evolve out of a better understanding of the underlying pathophysiology."
Conclusions and implications for future research are provided.

[No]
No sources of funding are described.

Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

P1: [Yes] "Functional, cosmetic and psychosexual results in adult men who underwent hypospadias correction in childhood"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

P2: [Yes] "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
The abstract provides a structured summary.

P3: [Yes] "Hypospadias is one of the most common urologic congenital anomalies and occurs in approximately 1 out of 250 newborn boys [1]. Hypospadias surgery aims to attain a straight urinary stream from a meatus with a normal anatomical position, a straight penis in erection, and normal cosmetic penile appearance."  
The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

P4: [Yes] "Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)."
The objectives are stated: "This review aims to present the results of long-term hypospadias studies in postpubertal men who had hypospadias correction at a young age."

P5: [No] 
No review protocol or registration is mentioned.

P6: [Yes] "Inclusion criteria stated that patients with hypospadias were operated before the age of 6 years and were older than 14 years at follow up."
Eligibility criteria for studies are provided. 

P7: [Yes] "The Pubmed/Medline and Embase databases were searched until February 2010."
The information sources are described.

P8: [No]
The search strategy is not provided.

P9: [Yes] "References of included papers were checked for possible missing studies." 
The study selection process is described.

P10: [No]  
The data collection process is not described.

The data items are not listed.

P12: [NA] 
Risk of bias assessment not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P13: [NA]
Summary measures not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed. 

P14: [NA]  
Synthesis methods not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P15: [NA]  
Risk of bias assessment across studies not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P16: [NA]
Additional analyses not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P17: [Yes] "Twenty eligible studies investigating micturition, cosmesis and psychosexual functioning were found."
The number of studies screened and included is provided. 

P18: [No]
Study characteristics are not presented in a table.

P19: [No]  
Risk of bias within individual studies is not presented.

P20: [No]
Results of individual studies are not shown with effect estimates.

P21: [NA] 
Results of meta-analyses not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P22: [NA]
Risk of bias across studies not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P23: [NA] 
Additional analyses not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed. 

P24: [Yes] "Patients with hypospadias are arguably better off in experienced hands in terms of short-term complications [36], [37]. Whether this is also true for long-term results is uncertain, but more experienced centers do contain higher volumes of patients eligible for follow up."
A summary of the evidence is provided.

P25: [Yes] "Studies on the long-term outcomes after hypospadias repair in childhood are scarce. They are characterized by high loss to follow up (51.6%), and heterogeneous patients and data, and they lack validated questionnaires and control groups." 
Limitations are discussed.

P26: [Yes] "In future studies, the cosmetic aspect should be evaluated using validated questionnaires only. This rules out subjectivity as much as possible and leads to outcomes that can be compared. Sexual function should be evaluated with a sexual questionnaire validated for young adults."
Conclusions and implications for future research are provided.

P27: [Yes] "None."
Funding sources are stated.

Study characteristics are not presented in a table.

P19: [No]  
Risk of bias within individual studies is not presented.

P20: [No]
Results of individual studies are not shown with effect estimates.

P21: [NA] 
Results of meta-analyses not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P22: [NA]
Risk of bias across studies not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P23: [NA] 
Additional analyses not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed. 

P24: [Yes] "Patients with hypospadias are arguably better off in experienced hands in terms of short-term complications [36], [37]. Whether this is also true for long-term results is uncertain, but more experienced centers do contain higher volumes of patients eligible for follow up."
A summary of the evidence is provided.

P25: [Yes] "Studies on the long-term outcomes after hypospadias repair in childhood are scarce. They are characterized by high loss to follow up (51.6%), and heterogeneous patients and data, and they lack validated questionnaires and control groups." 
Limitations are discussed.

P26: [Yes] "In future studies, the cosmetic aspect should be evaluated using validated questionnaires only. This rules out subjectivity as much as possible and leads to outcomes that can be compared. Sexual function should be evaluated with a sexual questionnaire validated for young adults."
Conclusions and implications for future research are provided.

P27: [Yes] "None."
Funding sources are stated.

llm_message:
Here are the responses for the PRISMA items based on the provided systematic review text:

[Yes] "Single-Incision Pediatric Endosurgery: A Systematic Review" 

The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes] "We performed a systematic review of the literature to find out the current state of SIPES procedures, including age, technical aspects, and operative outcomes."

The abstract describes the rationale, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, methods, and main results. 

[Yes] "In the search for less invasive procedures, ever since the development of laparoscopic surgery and with the limitations and equipment dependence of Natural Orifice Translumenal endoscopic surgery (NOTES®), this new approach through the umbilicus, a natural embrionary orifice,1 was first reported in 1992 by Pelosi and Pelosi."

The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

[Yes] "The objective of this review is to show the initial published experience about SIPES to evaluate its real benefits in terms of feasibility and clinical outcomes."  

The introduction provides an explicit statement of the review questions.

[No]

The methods do not indicate if a review protocol exists.

[Yes] "Articles were considered eligible if they met the following inclusion criteria: (1) Operations were performed through a single incision. (2) The target population was children under 18 years of age. (3) Operations performed exclusively by pediatric surgeons. (4) Series larger than 100 patients were included for appendectomy operations. (5) Case reports, case series, and comparative and prospective randomized trials were included in other, nonappendectomy, operations because of their low incidence. (6) Articles should include age, operative technical aspects, and operative outcomes."

The eligibility criteria relating to population, interventions, studies are described.

[Yes] "We performed an electronic search in PubMed up to March 2012 with the following terms: “single” AND “incision” OR “site” OR “port” OR “trocar” AND “children.” Related articles were also reviewed."

The information sources and search strategy are described.

[No] 

The search strategy is not presented in full for any database. 

[Yes] "The initial reports consisted of extracorporeal appendectomies (laparoscopic-assisted procedures). However, fully laparoscopic SIPES appendectomies without any requirement of special flexible or articulated instruments had been reported as well."

The process of study selection is described.

[No]

The data collection process is not described.

[Yes] "Ports were defined as the access device chosen to perform the single-incision surgery. In pediatrics, these include multilumen devices such as the SILSTM Port (Covidien, Inc., Mansfield, MA) or the TriPort (Advanced Surgical Concepts, Bray, Ireland, United Kingdom) or the use of multiple cannulas or the combination of one-cannula and stab fascial incisions for passage of the instruments through a single skin incision." 

The variables extracted are listed and defined.

[No]

Methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.

[Yes] "Operative time was described as a median or medium (in minutes) and range when mentioned."

The summary measures are stated.

[NA]

[NA] 

[NA]

[Yes]  "We identified a total of 4212 patients operated on by SIPES."

The number of studies screened, assessed, and included is provided, with reasons for exclusion.

[Yes] "Twelve articles fulfilled our inclusion criteria for SIPES appendectomy, including a total of 2422 patients."

For each study, characteristics such as interventions, participants, and outcomes are presented.

[No]

A risk of bias assessment is not presented for the included studies.

[Yes] "The mean operative time was longer with the SIPES approach in the prospective trial of St Peter et al., where a 10% conversion rate was described, a value similar to our 10.7% conversion rate found in this review (Table 5)."

For each outcome, summary data and effect sizes are presented for each study. 

[NA]

[NA]

[NA] 

[Yes] "In terms of pain, it is believed that a larger umbilical incision may translate into more postoperative pain. However, others have speculated that limiting the number of incisions means decreasing trauma to the tissue and translates into reduced pain. Unfortunately, we did not find a uniform pain assessment among authors, and others did not even mention it."

The synthesised findings are summarised, including the strength of evidence.

[Yes] "Further analysis could not be performed because of the weak nature of the evidence in the majority of publications and some methodological defects of the literature reviewed. The low incidence of some pediatric surgical diseases (favoring case series with low level of evidence) and the lack of uniformity in evaluating some measures among surgeons, like pain assessment or cosmesis, for example, are the main contributors to this limitation." 

The limitations at the study and outcome level, as well as at the review level, are discussed. 

[Yes] "From this systematic review we conclude: A wide experience in SIPES and its feasibility have already been described with good clinical outcomes and low rate of conversion."

The conclusions summarize the main findings and put them into context of other evidence.

[Yes] "No competing financial interests exist."

Sources of funding are described.

llm_message:
1. "Identify the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Quote: "Our study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing OD and LD pull-through techniques for HD."
Reasoning: Title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

2. "Provide a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions and implications."
Quote: "Abstract provides structured summary with background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, results, conclusions."  
Reasoning: Abstract provides a structured summary.
[Yes]

3. "Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known."  
Quote: "Despite the introduction of TERPT, the Duhamel technique still remains a relevant procedure favored by surgeons in both the open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) forms, particularly for long segment and redo procedures."
Reasoning: Introduction describes rationale for review.
[Yes]  

4. "Provide explicit questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design."
Quote: "Our study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing long-term outcomes for open Duhamel (OD) and laparoscopic Duhamel (LD) procedures for HD, to identify any added advantage of the laparoscopic technique."
Reasoning: Introduction provides explicit question comparing OD and LD procedures.
[Yes]

5. "Indicate if a review protocol exists and if available, provide registration information including registration number."
Quote: No mention of review protocol.
Reasoning: Review protocol not reported.  
[No]

6. "Specify study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility." 
Quote: "Exclusion criteria included patients with total colonic aganglionosis, follow-up of less than 6 months, cohorts smaller than 10 patients, full articles not written in English, and non–peer-reviewed articles. Studies with insufficient operation details or those that did not differentiate between the two approaches were also excluded."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria specified.
[Yes]

7. "Describe all information sources including databases, contact with authors, and date last searched."
Quote: "A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications that analyzed outcomes for LD or OD pull-through procedures for HD. All studies between January 1994 and December 2014 were included in the search." 
Reasoning: Information sources described.
[Yes]  

8. "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used."
Quote: No full search strategy presented.
Reasoning: Full search strategy not provided.
[No]

9. "State process for selecting studies including screening, eligibility, inclusion in review, and inclusion in meta-analysis."
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics and patient demographics. Outcome parameters included incidence of enterocolitis, constipation, fecal incontinence or soiling, and further surgery, length of operation, length of hospital stay, and time taken to tolerate full oral feeds."
Reasoning: Process for study selection described.
[Yes]

10. "Describe method of data extraction and processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
Quote: "Our review only included published studies, and no contact with authors was made to obtain unpublished data."
Reasoning: Data extraction methods described. 
[Yes]

11. "List and define all variables for which data were sought including assumptions and simplifications made."
Quote: "Data collected included study characteristics (author, journal, publication year, sample size, length of follow-up, and operative technique) and patient demographics (sex and age at surgery). Outcome parameters included incidence of enterocolitis, constipation, fecal incontinence or soiling, and further surgery, length of operation, length of hospital stay, and time taken to tolerate full oral feeds."
Reasoning: Variables defined.
[Yes]

12. "Describe methods for assessing risk of bias and how this information is to be used."
Quote: "Their risk of bias was assessed and summarized." 
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessment described.
[Yes]

13. "State principal summary measures."
Quote: "Odds ratios were calculated for dichotomous variables, and mean difference values were calculated for continuous variables."
Reasoning: Principal summary measures stated.
[Yes]

14. "Describe methods of handling data and combining results." 
Quote: No meta-analysis performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

15. "Specify assessment of risk of bias across studies."
Quote: No assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: Not reported.
[No] 

16. "Describe methods of additional analyses."
Quote: No additional analyses described.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

17. "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included with reasons for exclusion." 
Quote: "The initial literature search identified 132 articles published from 1994 to 2014. Of these, 114 did not fulfill the inclusion criteria and were excluded."
Reasoning: Study selection process described.
[Yes]

18. "Present characteristics of included studies and provide citations."
Quote: "Eleven articles met our strict inclusion criteria and were included in the meta-analysis." 
Reasoning: Included studies and citations provided in results.
[Yes]

19. "Present data on risk of bias for each study."
Quote: "Their risk of bias was assessed and summarized."
Reasoning: Risk of bias for each study presented.
[Yes]

20. "Present simple summary data, effect estimates, and confidence intervals for each study."
Quote: "The mean incidence of enterocolitis in the OD group was 15% (range, 0%–36%) compared with 10% (range, 0%–46%) in the LD group."
Reasoning: Summary data for studies presented. 
[Yes]

21. "Present results of meta-analyses including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."
Quote: No meta-analysis performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

22. "Present results of assessment of risk of bias across studies." 
Quote: No assessment of risk of bias across studies.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

23. "Give results of additional analyses."
Quote: No additional analyses performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

24. "Summarize main findings including strength of evidence for each outcome."
Quote: "Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD."
Reasoning: Main findings summarized.
[Yes]

25. "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level and at review level."
Quote: "The results of our meta-analysis should be carefully interpreted. The following are unavoidable limitations:"
Reasoning: Limitations discussed.
[Yes]

26. "Provide general interpretation of results in context of other evidence and implications for future research."
Quote: "Prospective, randomized control trials are required to overcome limitations in the current literature."
Reasoning: Results interpreted and implications described.
[Yes]

27. "Describe sources of funding and role of funders."
Quote: "No competing financial interests exist." 
Reasoning: Funding sources described.
[Yes]

13. "State principal summary measures."
Quote: "Odds ratios were calculated for dichotomous variables, and mean difference values were calculated for continuous variables."
Reasoning: Principal summary measures stated.
[Yes]

14. "Describe methods of handling data and combining results." 
Quote: No meta-analysis performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

15. "Specify assessment of risk of bias across studies."

Reasoning: Not reported.
[No] 

16. "Describe methods of additional analyses."

Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

17. "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included with reasons for exclusion."

[Yes]

18. "Present characteristics of included studies and provide citations."

Reasoning: Included studies and citations provided in results.
[Yes]

19. "Present data on risk of bias for each study."
Quote: "Their risk of bias was assessed and summarized."
Reasoning: Risk of bias for each study presented.
[Yes]

20. "Present simple summary data, effect estimates, and confidence intervals for each study."
Quote: "The mean incidence of enterocolitis in the OD group was 15% (range, 0%–36%) compared with 10% (range, 0%–46%) in the LD group."
Reasoning: Summary data for studies presented. 
[Yes]

21. "Present results of meta-analyses including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."
Quote: No meta-analysis performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

22. "Present results of assessment of risk of bias across studies."

Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

23. "Give results of additional analyses."
Quote: No additional analyses performed.
Reasoning: Not applicable.
[NA]

24. "Summarize main findings including strength of evidence for each outcome."
Quote: "Our meta-analysis convincingly demonstrates the superiority of LD over OD pull-through for HD."
Reasoning: Main findings summarized.
[Yes]

25. "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level and at review level."
Quote: "The results of our meta-analysis should be carefully interpreted. The following are unavoidable limitations:"
Reasoning: Limitations discussed.
[Yes]

26. "Provide general interpretation of results in context of other evidence and implications for future research."
Quote: "Prospective, randomized control trials are required to overcome limitations in the current literature."
Reasoning: Results interpreted and implications described.
[Yes]

27. "Describe sources of funding and role of funders."

[Yes]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and responses for each PRISMA item:

1. "Laparoscopic versus open repair of recto-bladderneck and recto-prostatic anorectal malformations: a systematic review and meta-analysis" [Yes]
2. The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis. [Yes]
3. "The objective of this review was to better document the available data understanding the challenges of a variety of outcome measures, few and heterogeneous patient samples and poor reporting." [Yes]   
4. "The objective of this review was to better document the available data understanding the challenges of a variety of outcome measures, few and heterogeneous patient samples and poor reporting." [Yes]
5. [No]
6. "Studies were included if they fulfilled the following criteria: (1) primary diagnosis of RB/RP-ARM; (2) male patients less than 18 years of age at the time of definitive repair of their RB/RP-ARM; (3) interventions include LAARP versus OPEN for ligation of the fistula and mobilization of the rectum;" [Yes]
7. "A comprehensive search was conducted of MEDLINE/PubMed, EMBASE/OVID and CENTRAL (the Cochrane Library) electronic databases from 2000 to March 2014." [Yes]  
8. "Grey literature was searched in PapersFirst, ProceedingsFirst and ProQuest electronic databases (keyword search)." [Yes]
9. "Title and abstract screening was conducted independently and in duplicate (AS and ML)." [Yes]
10. "Data abstraction was performed in duplicate (AS and ML) and verified for accuracy and quality via a pre-piloted standardized data abstraction form;" [Yes]
11. "We planned to assess other outcomes and investigations; however, data on these were insufficiently reported in the included studies, which precluded comparisons (e.g., estimated blood loss during the operation, the time to achieve full diet, routine postoperative cross-sectional imaging or length of hospital stay)." [Yes]
12. [NA]
13. "The principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." [Yes] 
14. "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." [Yes]
15. [NA]
16. [NA]
17. "From 3681 retrieved articles, 7 studies enrolling 187 patients were analyzed." [Yes]
18. "Patient characteristics of the included studies are summarized in Tables 1 and 2." [Yes]  
19. [NA]
20. "Mucosal prolapse is common after repair of ARMs and can lead to bleeding and excoriation and may interfere with continence [19]. It is treated by excision and revision of the anorectal anastomosis to reduce mucosa soiling and improve sensation in the neoanal canal [19]." [Yes]
21. "There was no significant difference in operative time (p = 0.89)." [Yes]
22. [NA]  
23. [NA]
24. "The pooled rate of mucosal prolapse and need for operative revision was not significantly different between LAARP compared to OPEN (p = 0.18)" [Yes]
25. "The overall quality of the evidence (GRADE) [29, 30] of the included articles was very low, and is summarized in the “GRADE Summary of Findings Table” (Table 3)." [Yes]
26. "We followed rigorous systematic review methodology to assess the outcomes of children with RB/RP-ARMs undergoing LAARP and open surgical approaches as per the clinical studies available." [Yes] 
27. "The authors would like to thank Neera Bhatnagar for her assistance with the search strategy, and Molly Barber for her assistance with editing the manuscript." [Yes]

llm_message:
Here is my assessment of the PRISMA reporting for the provided publication:

[Yes] "Laparoscopic versus open surgery in children with choledochal cysts: a meta-analysis"
Clearly identified as a meta-analysis in the title.

[Yes] "Objective: To compare the safety and efficacy between laparoscopic and open cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy for children with choledochal cysts using meta-analysis."
Provided structured background, objectives, methods, results and conclusions in the abstract.

[Yes] "Choledochal cysts are rare congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree that present primarily in female infants and young children and are more prevalent in East Asian populations [1, 2]."  
Described the rationale and context at the beginning of the introduction.

[Yes] "Objective: To compare the safety and efficacy between laparoscopic and open cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy for children with choledochal cysts using meta-analysis."
Stated the objectives with participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes (no study designs due to a meta-analysis). 

[No]
Did not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide registration information.

[Yes] "Inclusion criteria: (1) study reported on at least one of the outcome measures mentioned below: operative time, intraoperative blood loss, time to food intake, postoperative morbidity (including bile leakage, pancreatic leakage, cholangitis, pancreatitis, adhesive intestinal obstruction, abdominal bleeding, etc.) and mortality, length of hospital stay; (2) population: children younger than 18 years with choledochal cysts; (3) intervention: laparoscopic cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (LH) versus open cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy (OH)."
Specified eligibility criteria including participants, interventions, comparisons, and outcomes.

[Yes] "We searched databases, including PubMed, Embase, the Science Citation Index, and Cochrane Library updated to November 2014, to identify all related published studies comparing the laparoscopic and the open choledochal cyst excision with hepaticojejunostomy."
Described the information sources including databases and dates searched.

[No]
Did not present the full electronic search strategy for any database. 

[Yes] "According to the search strategy described previously, a total of 162 citations were obtained for review of title and abstract. Of the 162 citations, 14 duplicates were removed by the Endnote X5 software, and 131 irrelevant studies were excluded through scanning titles and abstracts."
Stated the process of study screening and selection.

[No] 
Did not describe the data extraction process.

[Yes] "Information about the characteristics of the study population, authors, publication year, study period, country, sample size, interventions, outcomes details of the surgical techniques used, and relevant outcomes were recorded."
Listed the data items extracted.

[NA]
No assessment of individual study bias (meta-analysis).

[Yes] "The outcomes were operative time, intraoperative blood loss, time to food intake, postoperative morbidity and mortality, length of hospital stay." 
Stated the summary measures used.

[Yes] "Heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistic. In case of lack of heterogeneity, fixed-effects model was used for the meta-analysis, or else random-effects model was used to explain it."
Described methods for combining study results and assessing heterogeneity. 

[NA]
No assessment of publication bias (optional in meta-analyses).

[NA] 
No additional analyses mentioned.

[Yes] "According to the search strategy described previously, a total of 162 citations were obtained for review of title and abstract. Of the 162 citations, 14 duplicates were removed by the Endnote X5 software, and 131 irrelevant studies were excluded through scanning titles and abstracts. Reviewers had perfect agreement in selecting the 7 studies [9–15] considered to be suitable for the final meta-analysis using the stated eligibility criteria." 
Presented the study selection process and numbers at each stage with reasons for exclusions.

[Yes] Table 1
Presented the characteristics of the included studies.

[NA] 
No assessment of individual study bias (meta-analysis).

[Yes] Figures 1-5
Presented simple summary data and effect estimates with confidence intervals for all outcomes.

[Yes] Figures 1-5
Presented results of each meta-analysis with confidence intervals and measures of heterogeneity.

[NA]
No assessment of bias across studies (optional in meta-analyses). 

[NA]
No additional analyses mentioned.

[Yes] "In conclusion, laparoscopic cyst excision with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is a safe and effective treatment option for choledochal cysts in children with comparable outcomes to open resection."
Summarized the main findings and their relevance.

[Yes] "This meta-analysis has some limitations that should be taken into account when considering the results. First, there are no randomized trials comparing the two procedures. All seven included studies are retrospective studies which are prone to selection bias and may result in uneven distribution of confounding factors such as age of patient, duration of follow-up and type of choledochal cysts."
Discussed limitations at the study and outcome level.

[Yes] "In conclusion, laparoscopic cyst excision with Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy is a safe and effective treatment option for choledochal cysts in children with comparable outcomes to open resection. With more refinement in equipment and technique, it will be possible to consider LH as a gold standard for treatment of pediatric choledochal cysts."
Provided general interpretation and implications for future research.

[No]
No statement about sources of funding or other support.

llm_message:
P1. "[Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) for major urological procedures in the pediatric population: A systematic review]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. "In this review, we aim to elucidate the aspects of LESS for major urological procedures in the pediatric population." - The abstract provides background and objectives. [Yes] 

P3. "Recent improvements in laparoscopic surgical techniques have led to the introduction of laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS), as an alternative to conventional laparoscopy (CL) conferring a number of possible advantages...As such, there is still a lack of comprehensive evidence regarding the feasibility, safety and efficacy of LESS for urologic procedures in children." - The introduction describes the rationale in context of what is already known. [Yes]

P4. "Inclusion criteria were: 1) pediatric patient population (age <18 years) 2) single site approach initially selected by the surgeon, 3) procedure carried out completely laparoendoscopically, 4) major urological procedure performed were limited to: nephrectomy, nephroureterectomy, pyeloplasty, varicocelectomy and partial nephrectomy 5) study population of more than one patient." - The introduction provides objectives with reference to participants, interventions, outcomes, and study design. [Yes]

P5. "[Yes]" - A review protocol is not mentioned.  

P6. "Inclusion criteria were: 1) pediatric patient population (age <18 years) 2) single site approach initially selected by the surgeon, 3) procedure carried out completely laparoendoscopically, 4) major urological procedure performed were limited to: nephrectomy, nephroureterectomy, pyeloplasty, varicocelectomy and partial nephrectomy 5) study population of more than one patient." - Eligibility criteria for studies are specified. [Yes]

P7. "An in-depth search of the literature was performed in the databases of PubMed and Scopus" - The information sources searched are described. [Yes]

P8. "[Yes]" - The full electronic search strategy is not presented. 

P9. "Two reviewers (ENS and DN) working independently extracted data from all eligible studies; any discrepancies were discussed and consensus was reached." - The study selection process is described. [Yes] 

P10. "Data on parameters such as operation time, instrumentation, perioperative complications, hospital stay and follow up period were collected and further analyzed cumulatively." - The data collection process from studies is described. [Yes]  

P11. "From each eligible study the following parameters were extracted when available: general study characteristics (author, date of publication), patient demographics (age and gender), procedure performed, indication, site of incision, details of surgical technique (entry device employed, access route, size of incision, laparoscopic instruments used, total operation time), intraoperative complications (including conversion to open surgery, use of additional ports and estimated blood loss (EBL)) and surgical outcome (length of hospital stay and post-operative complications)." - The variables extracted are listed. [Yes]

P12. "[Yes]" - Risk of bias assessment is not described. 

P13. "[Yes]" - Summary measures are not applicable for this descriptive review.  

P14. "[Yes]" - Methods of combining study results are not applicable. 

P15. "[Yes]" - Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable. 

P16. "[Yes]" - Additional analyses are not described. 

P17. "Fig. 1. PRISMA flow diagram of Laparoendoscopic Single-Site Surgery (LESS) for major urologic procedures." - The study selection process is presented in a figure. [Yes]

P18. "In total 29 studies met the inclusion criteria; these included data from 54 patients who underwent partial nephrectomy/nephroureterectomy, 165 and 19 patients who underwent transperitoneal and retroperitoneal nephrectomy/nephroureterectomy respectively, 91 patients who underwent pyeloplasty and 57 patients who underwent varicocelectomy." - Study characteristics are presented. [Yes]

P19. "[Yes]" - Assessment of risk of bias within studies is not presented.  

P20. "Tables 1-6 present data on operation time, complications, hospital stay for the included studies." - Results for individual studies are presented in tables. [Yes]

P21. "[Yes]" - Results of syntheses are not applicable. 

P22. "[Yes]" - Results of bias assessment across studies are not applicable. 

P23. "[Yes]" - Results of additional analyses are not applicable. 

P24. "In the hands of experienced surgeons LESS seems a feasible and attractive alternative to CL with comparable results." - Main findings are summarized. [Yes]

P25. "However given that the majority of studies included in this systematic review were either case-series or retrospective cohort studies with the risk of bias, especially publication-bias, remaining unambiguous, the results should be interpreted with caution." - Study limitations are discussed. [Yes] 

P26. "There is an imperative need of well-designed prospective randomized trials, with large number of patients, in order to clarify the safety and long term efficacy of LESS for urological procedures in the pediatric population." - Conclusions are provided. [Yes]

P27. "No funding received." - Sources of funding are described. [Yes]

"However given that the majority of studies included in this systematic review were either case-series or retrospective cohort studies with the risk of bias, especially publication-bias, remaining unambiguous, the results should be interpreted with caution." - Study limitations are discussed. [Yes] 

P26. "There is an imperative need of well-designed prospective randomized trials, with large number of patients, in order to clarify the safety and long term efficacy of LESS for urological procedures in the pediatric population." - Conclusions are provided. [Yes]

P27. "No funding received." - Sources of funding are described. [Yes]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

1. "Laparoscopic assistance for primary transanal pull-through in Hirschsprung's disease: a systematic review and meta-analysis"

The report is identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis. [Yes]

2. "We present evidence from five retrospective studies of 405 patients. This is the first study to systematically review the available literature comparing totally transanal endorectal pull-through procedures with laparoscopically assisted pull-through procedures."

The abstract provides a structured summary covering all key elements. [Yes]

3. "In a recent survey of practice in the UK, the majority of responding surgeons who utilise an endorectal dissection employ laparoscopic surgery for biopsies or mobilisation. The aim of this study was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to compare outcomes for infants with Hirschsprung's disease undergoing a TTERPT procedure with those undergoing a laparoscopically assisted transanal pull-through (LAPT)."  

The rationale and context for the review are described. [Yes]

4. "The aim of this study was to conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to compare outcomes for infants with Hirschsprung's disease undergoing a TTERPT procedure with those undergoing a laparoscopically assisted transanal pull-through (LAPT)."

The objective comparing TTERPT and LAPT interventions is stated. [Yes]  

5. "A study protocol outlining the search strategy, outcomes, and methods of data extraction and statistical analysis was designed and prospectively registered with the Prospero database (CRD42013005698)."

The protocol registration is mentioned. [Yes]

6. "Study inclusion and exclusion criteria are summarised in table 1." 

Eligibility criteria are specified in Table 1. [Yes]

7. "We searched all publications from 1 January 1998 to 1 January 2014 from EMBASE, MEDLINE and Cochrane library databases using the search strategy detailed in online supplementary appendix I."

Information sources and search dates are described. [Yes]

8. "We searched all publications from 1 January 1998 to 1 January 2014 from EMBASE, MEDLINE and Cochrane library databases using the search strategy detailed in online supplementary appendix I."

The full search strategy is provided in the appendix. [Yes] 

9. "Titles and abstracts of potentially relevant papers were screened by two independent authors (DT and BA). The full texts of all identified studies were assessed against the criteria in table 1 by the two independent authors (DT and BA), and study reference lists were hand searched for potentially relevant studies."

The study selection process is described. [Yes]

10. "Data were extracted by the two independent authors (DT and BA) using a predesigned proforma."

Data extraction by two independent authors is mentioned. [Yes]

11. "Data were collected regarding: age at gestation, diagnosis and surgery, level of anal dissection, length of mucosal cuff, length and location of aganglionosis, and any congenital abnormalities." 

Variables extracted are listed. [Yes]

12. "Study quality was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for case–control and cohort studies."

Risk of bias assessment is mentioned. [Yes] 

13. "Continuous data were analysed using an inverse variance model to produce a mean difference. Dichotomous variables were analysed using a Mantel-Haenszel model to produce ORs."

Summary measures are stated. [Yes]

14. [NA] 

15. [NA] 

16. [NA]

17. "A total of 2107 records were screened, of which 41 studies potentially met the eligibility criteria (figure 1). Thirty-one studies were excluded because there was no comparative study arm. Two were excluded because they used a posterior sagittal rather than a transanal approach. One study was excluded because it used a laparoscopic Duhamel-type anastomosis and one study because infants undergoing a staged procedure were pooled with primary procedure results."

The results of the study selection process are summarized. [Yes]

18. "Table 2 summarises the characteristics of included studies."

Study characteristics are presented in Table 2. [Yes]

19. "Study quality was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for case–control and cohort studies." 

Risk of bias within studies is mentioned. [Yes]

20. "Analysis using a fixed-effects model revealed a mean difference of 50.29 min shorter operative time with a totally transanal technique (95% CI 60.74 to 39.83, p<0.00001)."

Results for operative time are summarized. [Yes]

21. [NA]

22. [NA] 

23. [NA]

24. "In general, these studies were of low quality, featuring heterogeneity with respect to outcome assessment, limited adjustment for potential confounders and inadequate long-term follow-up." 

Key findings are summarized. [Yes]

25. "Despite acknowledgement that more complicated and extensive disease segments require some form of intra-abdominal approach, including laparoscopy, minilaparotomy, umbilical incision or formal laparotomy, there is currently a lack of guidance to determine when it is unsafe to attempt a TTERPT."

Limitations at study and outcome level are discussed. [Yes]

26. "The issues we have raised regarding choice of operation would be best resolved by randomisation within a clinical trial of TTERPT versus LAPT approaches in patients with aganglionosis confined to the rectum and sigmoid colon on radiological assessment." 

Implications for future research are described. [Yes]

27. "MK is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship."

Funding is stated. [Yes]

llm_message:
[Yes] 
"Balloon dilatation of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia: a systematic review"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes]
"Here we review the current evidence of the outcomes of balloon dilatation of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia in children."  
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, and conclusions.

[Yes] 
"Benign oesophageal strictures in children may occur as a result of congenital anomalies or complications secondary to either caustic gastro-oesophageal reflux or surgical correction of oesophageal atresia."
The introduction describes the rationale in context of existing knowledge.  

[Yes]
"In this review, we sought to review the current published evidence of the outcomes of balloon dilatation of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia."
The objectives are stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.

[No]
A review protocol was not mentioned.

[Yes] 
"Outcomes of interest were success of balloon dilatation (dysphagia improvement), incidence of oesophageal perforation and requirement of stent placement and/or oesophageal surgery (revision of anastomosis and/or oesophageal replacement)."
Eligibility criteria are specified including outcomes of interest.

[Yes]
"We searched the standard databases (January, 1960–May, 2012): MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane Library Controlled Trials Register (CENTRAL) using the MeSH Terms “esophageal stricture”, “esophageal stenosis” and “balloon dilatation” to identify the studies." 
Information sources including databases and dates are described.

[No]
A full search strategy is not presented.

[Yes]
"We decided, a priori, to limit our review to studies that reported outcomes of balloon dilatation (both endoscopically and under fluoroscopic control) of anastomotic strictures secondary to surgical repair of oesophageal atresia in children. There was no language restriction."
The study selection process is described.

[Yes] 
"Two reviewers (M.T. and A.T.) independently abstracted data from all studies onto a predefined data collection form."
The data collection process is described.

[Yes]
"Outcomes of interest were success of balloon dilatation (dysphagia improvement), incidence of oesophageal perforation and requirement of stent placement and/or oesophageal surgery (revision of anastomosis and/or oesophageal replacement)."
Variables extracted are listed.

[No] 
Risk of bias assessment is not described. 

[NA]
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]  
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No assessment of bias across studies is described.

[NA]
No additional analyses are mentioned. 

[Yes]
"We identified 26 studies from our search that were deemed relevant and these were further scrutinised for eligibility for inclusion in this review. Only five studies met the inclusion criteria; 21 studies were excluded for reasons outlined in the selection flow chart in Fig. 1."
Study selection is depicted in a flow diagram.

[Yes]
"Table 1 shows the characteristics of all the studies included in this review." 
Study characteristics are presented in a table.

[No]
Risk of bias within studies is not presented.

[Yes] 
"Tables 1 and 2."
Summary data and effect estimates are presented for each study in tables. 

[NA] 
No meta-analysis results to synthesize.

[NA]
No assessment of bias across studies.

[NA]
No additional analyses mentioned.

[Yes]
"In total, at least 60% used general anaesthesia. The size of balloon catheter ranged from 4 mm to 22 mm (Tables 1 and 2)."
Main findings are summarized including outcomes.

[No]
Limitations are not discussed.

[Yes]  
"Balloon dilatation for anastomotic strictures post-oesophageal atresia repair is safe, and associated with a low perforation and mortality rates, and approximately three dilatations are required per child. The perforation rates are very low and most perforations are amenable to non-operative management."
Conclusions are provided in context of evidence.

[No]
Funding sources are not described.

[No] "To ascertain differences in outcome between the minimally invasive and open surgical approaches for the treatment of solid intra‐abdominal or intra‐thoracic neoplasms in children."

Reports the number of studies screened and included/excluded.

[Yes] "Even though results from adult RCTs in patients with colon cancer are promising (Buunen 2009; Lacy 2002; Leung 2004), the extrapolation of results from studies in adults to children is not possible, due to the different tumour biology of adult and paediatric malignancies, and the differences in the therapy and prognosis of cancer in children."

[Yes] "Even though RCTs are the highest level of evidence, it should be recognised that data from non-randomised studies on the use of MIS in different types of solid intra‐thoracic and intra‐abdominal childhood tumours are available (Al‐Shanafey 2008; Castilho 2002; Duarte 2009; Iwanaka 2004; Leclair 2007; Metzelder 2007; Sailhamer 2003; Shanberg 2006; Spurbeck 2004; Varlet 2009; Warmann 2003). Although the results of these studies are promising they should be interpreted with caution due to the biases associated with non-randomised study designs."

The methods describe the method of data extraction from reports and processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

[Yes] "To Split or Not to Split: Colostomy Complications for Anorectal Malformations or Hirschsprung Disease: A Single Center Experience and a Systematic Review of the Literature"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes] "Introduction The aim of this article is to identify the ideal type and location of colostomy in children with colorectal disease."  
The abstract provides a structured summary including the objectives.

[Yes] "Introduction Anorectal malformations and Hirschsprung disease are congenital malformations that show a wide clinical variety."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review. 

[Yes] "Introduction The location of the stoma on the colon (or ileum) is determined by the position of the transition zone."
The introduction provides objectives with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.

[NA]
No review protocol or registration is mentioned.

[Yes] "Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria Studies were eligible for inclusion when they reported a series of neonates (newborns under the age of 28 days) whose anorectal malformation or Hirschsprung disease was treated with a stoma, and reported on stoma type and location, complications of stoma formation or closure or mortality rates."
The eligibility criteria are specified.

[Yes] "Search Strategy The described search strategy yielded 877 citations in PubMed, 1,103 in Embase, and 367 in Web of Science." 
The information sources are described.

[Yes] "Search Strategy The general search terms were the same for the three databases, which are as follows: anorectal malformations, Hirschsprung disease, colostomy, and children. The exact search strategies are shown in Appendix 1."
The full electronic search strategy is presented for one database.

[Yes] "Study Selection The two investigators selected the articles independently, extracted literature data, and recorded them in purpose-designed forms."
The study selection process is described.

[No] 
The data collection process is not described.

The data items are listed and defined.

[NA]
No additional analyses like sensitivity analyses were mentioned.

A flow diagram of study selection is provided.

[Yes] "Results The eight studies included a total of 2,954 patients." 
Study characteristics are presented.

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented.

[NA]
No meta-analysis was performed so results of individual studies are not applicable. 

[NA] 
No meta-analysis was performed so results of syntheses are not applicable.

[NA]
No assessment of bias across studies is presented. 

[NA]
No additional analyses are mentioned.

[Yes] "Discussion A relatively high complication rate is described in colostomy formation in children with an anorectal malformation or Hirschsprung disease."
A summary of evidence is provided.

[Yes] "Discussion The wide range of complication rates in the systematic review may be because of the inconsistency in defining complications."
Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.

[Yes] "Conclusion The procedure of colostomy formation in anorectal malformations and Hirschsprung disease is meticulous and should be performed with great care." 
Conclusions are made including implications for practice.

llm_message:
Here are the assessments for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

P1. [Yes] "Incidence of metachronous contralateral inguinal hernias in children following unilateral repair — A meta-analysis of prospective studies☆"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. [No] There is no structured abstract.

P3. [Yes] "The aim of the present meta-analysis study is to systematically appraise the incidence of metachronous contralateral childhood inguinal hernia following unilateral inguinal hernia repair using data from well-designed prospective studies."  
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

P4. [No] The objectives do not explicitly state the PICOS elements. 

P5. [NA] A review protocol is not mentioned.

P6. [Yes] "Inclusion criteria consisted of prospective observational studies (a), with minimal follow-up time of one year (b), assessing newborns, infants, children, adolescents and young adults, aged from 0 to 19 years (c), without contralateral groin exploration or laparoscopic closure of CPPV (d)."
The eligibility criteria relating to study characteristics and report characteristics are described.

P7. [Yes] "The Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (The Cochrane library Issue 7 of 12, July 2014), MEDLINE (January 1966 to August 2014) and EMBASE (1947 to August 2014) were searched (Appendix 1 for detailed search strategy)."
The information sources including databases, dates of coverage, and search date are described.

P8. [Yes] "For MEDLINE search the following search term was used: ‘(Infant OR Child OR Adolescent) AND ("inguinal Hernia" OR "processus vaginalis") AND (Incidence OR "Treatment Outcome" OR Recurrence OR Laparoscopy OR contralateral OR Surgery OR Examination) AND (english[Language] OR german[Language])’."
The full electronic search strategy for one database is provided.

P9. [Yes] "Six studies met the inclusion criteria [7], [28], [29], [30], [31], [32]." 
The process of study screening and selection is described.

P10. [No] The data collection process is not described.

P11. [No] The variables for which data were sought are not listed or defined.

P12. [No] Methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.

P13. [Yes] "Since the test for heterogeneity was significant (p-value < 0.001), results from the random effect model were used."
The principal summary measures are stated.

P14. [NA] There is no meta-analysis performed.

P15. [NA] Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable without a meta-analysis.

P16. [NA] Additional analyses are not applicable without a meta-analysis. 

P17. [Yes] "Six studies met the inclusion criteria [7], [28], [29], [30], [31], [32]. One study was restricted to male children aged 0.5 to 2 years [28]. In total 1669 children were included."
The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are described with reasons for exclusion.

P18. [Yes] Table 1 provides the characteristics of the included studies.

P19. [No] Risk of bias assessments for individual studies are not presented.

P20. [Yes] Figure 1 provides a forest plot with summary data and effect estimates with confidence intervals for each included study. 

P21. [NA] Results of meta-analyses are not applicable without a meta-analysis.

P22. [NA] Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not applicable without a meta-analysis.

P23. [NA] Additional analyses are not applicable without a meta-analysis.

P24. [Yes] "The present meta-analysis shows that the overall risk of MCIH in children (aged 0–19 years) is 6%."
A summary of the main findings and their relevance is provided.

P25. [Yes] "Lack of uniformity in age restrictions and variation in inclusion and exclusion criteria (e.g. exclusion of patients with ascites) that were applied in different analyses may also have impacted on results [28], [29], [30], [31] (Table 1)."
Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.

P26. [Yes] "The present meta-anlaysis shows that the overall risk of MCIH in children (aged 0–19 years) is 6%. The risk of MCIH development is significantly greater in children with initial left-sided hernia (8.5% vs. 3.3%) and in children with open CPV (13.8% vs. 3%)." 
The findings are interpreted in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are described.

P27. [Yes] "There was no conflict of interest."
Sources of funding and other support are described along with the role of funders.
