[Yes]
"Robot-Assisted Minimally Invasive Surgery for Pediatric Solid Tumors: A Systematic Review of Feasibility and Current Status"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes] 
"Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
The abstract provides a structured summary covering all key elements.

[Yes]
"Surgical resection is a key component of multimodal treatment strategies for many pediatric solid tumors. With overall cure rates for childhood tumors approaching 80%,[1] there is an incentive to seek further means for improved quality of life through reduced surgery-related morbidity."  
The introduction describes the rationale for the review.

[Yes]
"The aim of this study is to systematically review the current status of robot-assisted MIS for pediatric solid tumors and critically appraise whether the evidence supports further exploration and adoption."
The objectives are stated.

[Yes]
"The review protocol was registered on the PROSPERO international prospective database of systematic reviews (CRD42013003752)."
Protocol registration is reported.

[Yes] 
"Inclusion criteria were defined as (1) clinical procedures in children (< 18 years or treated with internationally recognized pediatric oncology protocols, i.e., Children's Oncology Group or European Pediatric Oncology Group), (2) therapeutic MIS for resection of benign or malignant solid tumor(s), and (3) utilization of a robotic surgical platform." 
Eligibility criteria are specified.

[Yes]
"A systematic search of multiple electronic databases was undertaken (PubMed, Ovid Medline, and EMBASE) ([Fig. 1]).[21] The search period was for the years 2002 to 2012 inclusively."
Information sources are described. 

[Yes]
"Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated."
The full search strategy for PubMed is presented.

[Yes] 
"Two reviewers (T.P.C. and H.J.M.) independently undertook title and abstract screen, with disagreements resolved by consensus."
The study selection process is described.

[Yes]
"Corresponding authors were contacted in the event of insufficient data being reported in studies, such as mixed adult/pediatric series without age category subclassification."
The data collection process is described.

[Yes]
"Patient demographic information, operative details, oncological outcomes, and surgical complications were retrieved from included studies."
The data items collected are listed.

[NA]
No risk of bias assessment was performed for individual studies.

[Yes] 
"Almost universally, authors commented that the dexterity of seven degree-of-freedom articulated instruments, along with intuitive master-slave control permitted more meticulous dissection during tumor extirpation.[17] [20] [22] [23] [27] [28] [31] [33] [34] [35] [36] [38] [39]"
A narrative synthesis of results is provided. 

[NA]
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias across studies was performed.

[NA]
No additional analyses were reported.

[Yes]
"A total of 23 publications met eligibility criteria, reporting 40 cases overall. " 
The number of studies screened and included is reported.

"Patient demographic information, operative details, and patient outcomes for identified cases of robot-assisted MIS for pediatric solid tumors"
Characteristics of included studies are presented in a table.

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias within studies was performed.

Results for the main outcomes are reported.

[NA]
No additional analyses were performed.

"For the diverse and highly selective cases in this review, robot-assisted MIS seems safe and feasible."

[Yes]
"Lack of tactile feedback (haptics) was frequently cited as a primary technical concern.[17] [19] [23] [28]" 
Study limitations are discussed.

[No]

[Yes] "The publications were identified by searching the major medical databases such as MEDLINE, EMBASE, and Cochrane Library for relevant papers published between January 1992 and July 2012." 

[No] No full search strategy provided.

[Yes] "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."

[Yes] "Three researchers extracted data from each study by using a structured sheet and entered the data into a database. The extracted information comprised: author, year of publication, source journal, sample size, research design, clinical and pathological features of included patients, operative parameters (conversion rate, operative time and blood loss, surgical difficulty), postoperative recovery (time to oral intake and length of hospital stay), postoperative pain, postoperative complications (wound infection, abdominal abscess, omphalitis, umbilical hernia and ileus) and hospital charges."

[NA] No meta-analysis performed.

llm_message:
[Yes]
"Systematic Review of Level 1 Evidence for Laparoscopic Pediatric Surgery: Do Our Procedures Comply with the Requirements of Evidence-Based Medicine?"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes] 
"The aim of our study was to evaluate the availability of Level 1 studies comparing laparoscopic procedures with the corresponding open operation in pediatric surgery."
The abstract provides a structured summary including the objective.

[Yes]
"The implementation of well-designed RCTs, comparing minimally invasive procedures with the corresponding open operation in children has been claimed by several authors."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.

[Yes]
"Thus, the aim of our study was to present a current analysis of the Level 1 studies directly comparing laparoscopic and open operations in pediatric patients."  
The introduction provides explicit objectives relating to evaluating Level 1 evidence comparing laparoscopic and open pediatric surgery.

[NA]

[Yes]
"Clinical Level 1 studies (SR, MA, and RCT) published in the English literature were identified through a Medline literature search using PubMed."
The methods specify inclusion criteria relating to study design, language, and publication status. 

[Yes] 
"A total of 20 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria for our SR, of which 9 were SRs or MAs and 11 RCTs."
The methods describe the information sources including databases searched.

[No]

[Yes]
"Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those of studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of laparoscopic procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis."
The methods state the process for study screening and selection.

[NA]

[Yes]
"Endpoints of our analysis were advantages and disadvantages of laparoscopy compared with the open operation."
The methods list the data variables sought relating to outcomes.

[NA] 

[NA]

[NA]

[NA]

[NA]

[Yes]  
"A total of 20 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria for our SR, of which 9 were SRs or MAs and 11 RCTs."
The results report the number of records screened, assessed, and included with reasons for exclusions.

[Yes]
"Studies providing evidence of Level 1a were identified for five different types of laparoscopic procedures (appendectomy, inguinal hernia repair, orchidopexy, pyloromyotomy, and varicocelectomy)." 
The results present key characteristics of the included studies.

[NA]

[Yes]
"The incidence of wound infection was 1.5% after laparoscopic versus 5% after open appendectomy." 
The results present summary data and effect estimates for relevant outcomes.

[NA]

[NA] 

[NA]

[Yes]
"The authors wish to line out that it is neither their aim to condemn the evolving techniques in laparoscopic pediatric surgery nor the principles of evidence-based medicine."
The discussion summarizes the main findings and considers their relevance.

[Yes]
"Nevertheless, our SR of the literature clearly showed that Level 1 evidence is only available for seven different procedures in pediatric surgery."
The discussion acknowledges the limitation of few Level 1 studies available. 

[Yes] 
"Effort has to be made to extend the existing Level 1 evidence to open questions concerning these seven procedures and to gain high level evidence for further laparoscopic procedures in pediatric surgery."
The conclusion provides implications for future research.

[No]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
"[Yes] Surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents"
The title identifies this as a systematic review.

P2. Abstract: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number. 
"[Yes] This is the abstract."
The abstract provides a structured summary covering all applicable elements.

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
"[Yes] The prevalence of overweight and obese children and adolescents has increased throughout the world, presenting a global public health crisis..."
The introduction describes the rationale in the context of rising childhood obesity prevalence. 

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
"[Yes] To assess the effects of surgery for treating obesity in children and adolescents."
The objective clearly states the aim to assess the effects of obesity surgery in children and adolescents.

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
"[NA]"
No protocol or registration is mentioned.

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow‐up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
"[Yes] We included randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of surgical interventions for treating obesity in children and adolescents (age < 18 years) with a minimum of six months follow‐up." 
Eligibility criteria for study design, participants, interventions, and follow-up are clearly specified.

P7. Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.
"[Yes] We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE, LILACS, ClinicalTrials.gov, and WHO ICTRP from database inception to March 2015."
A comprehensive list of information sources searched is provided.

P8. Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
"[Yes] For detailed search strategies see Appendix 1."
The appendix provides the full search strategy for MEDLINE. 

P9. Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).
"[Yes] Two review authors independently screened records, assessed full texts for eligibility, and resolved discrepancies through consensus."
The process for study selection is clearly described.

P10. Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.
"[Yes] Two review authors independently extracted data using a standard form from the CMED Group." 
The data extraction process is described.

P11. Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.
"[Yes] Data were extracted on participant and intervention characteristics, efficacy outcomes, and adverse events."
Data items sought are listed.

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.
"[Yes] Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool, and evaluated the impact of bias on study results."
Methods for assessing individual study risk of bias are described.

P13. Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).
"[Yes] For dichotomous outcomes we calculated odds ratio or risk ratio and for continuous outcomes we calculated the mean difference."
Summary measures used are stated.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.  
"[NA]" 
Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).
"[NA]"
Not applicable as only one study was included. 

P16. Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
"[NA]"
No additional analyses were performed.

P17. Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
"[Yes] 2405 records screened, 11 full texts assessed, and 1 study included. A flow diagram is provided."
The study selection process is described and depicted in a flow diagram.

P18. Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.
"[Yes] Characteristics including sample size, interventions, outcomes, and follow-up are presented for the included study."
Study characteristics are presented. 

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).
"[Yes] Risk of bias is presented in a summary figure and detailed in the text."
Risk of bias assessments are presented.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.
"[Yes] Summary data, effect estimates, and confidence intervals are presented for outcomes in the one included study."
Results for each outcome are presented.

P21. Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
"[NA]" 
No meta-analysis was performed.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).
"[NA]"
Only one study was included so this is not applicable.

P23. Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).
"[NA]"
No additional analyses were performed. 

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).
"[Yes] The main findings and strength of evidence are summarized."
The main findings and limitations are summarized.

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
"[Yes] Limitations at the study and review level are discussed."
Limitations are discussed.

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
"[Yes] Conclusions are provided in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are described."
Conclusions and implications are discussed.

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
"[No]"
Sources of funding are not described.

llm_message:
[Yes] "Laparoscopic Versus Open Inguinal Hernia Repair in Pediatric Patients: A Systematic Review"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review.

[Yes] The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
It has a structured abstract.

[Yes] "The incidence of an inguinal hernia in children less than 18 years of age ranges from 0.8% to 4.4%.1 Eighty-five percent of patients with an inguinal hernia present with a unilateral hernia.1 The incidence of incarceration in the unrepaired hernia in infants and young children seems to vary between 6% and 18%, but it increases to approximately 30% in infancy, with a potential risk to the bowel and testicle.2 Bilateral inguinal hernia is significantly more common in younger patients (present in 50% if less than 1 year, 45% if less than 2 years, and 37% if less than 5 years)." 
The introduction describes the rationale and context for the review.

[Yes] "This review aims to evaluate the role of LH in children and to compare LH with OH in regard to operative time, postoperative complications, recurrence rate, discovering of rare hernias, and incidence of contralateral patency."
The introduction states the objectives and PICOS elements. 

[No] The methods do not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide registration information.

[Yes] "Eligibility criteria included all available studies focused on LH and/or OH and with quantitative data on outcome parameters. The pediatric population was defined as younger than 18 years when the patient underwent LH or OH."
The eligibility criteria are specified.

[Yes] "A literature search was performed using PubMed, Cochrane, and Medline databases on all studies published during the last 20 years that described open or laparoscopic operation for inguinal hernia, and the latter was compared with conventional OH. The following key words were used: “inguinal hernia,” “herniorrhaphy,” “hernia repair,” “children,” “laparoscopic versus open herniorrhaphy,” “laparoscopic versus open hernia repair,” “contralateral patency,” “complications,” and “recurrence.”"
The information sources and search strategy are described.

[No] The full electronic search strategy is not provided for any database. 

[Yes] "The authors independently assessed selected studies and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form. Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, publication date, study method, participant features, intervention characteristics, definition of complications, and outcome measures. Outcome parameters for inclusion were patients' age, gender, affected side, operative time, time to resume full activity, duration of hospital stay, recurrence, metachronic contralateral hernia, and complications."
The study selection process is described.

[Yes] "The authors independently assessed selected studies and tabulated data from each article with a predefined data extraction form." 
The data collection process is described.

[Yes] "Outcome parameters for inclusion were patients' age, gender, affected side, operative time, time to resume full activity, duration of hospital stay, recurrence, metachronic contralateral hernia, and complications."
The data items extracted are listed. 

[No] The methods used for assessing risk of bias are not described.

[Yes] "The chi-squared or Fisher's exact test was used to evaluate the significance of differences between the two groups: LH and OH."
The principal summary measures are stated.

[NA] Synthesis methods are not described as no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA] Assessment of bias across studies is not described as no meta-analysis was performed. 

[NA] No additional analyses are described as no meta-analysis was performed.

[Yes] Figure 1 shows the flow diagram of study selection.

[Yes] Table 1 presents characteristics of the included studies such as sample sizes and operative times.

[No] Individual study risk of bias is not presented.

[Yes] Tables 1 and 2 present operative time and recurrence rate data for individual studies.

[NA] Results of meta-analyses are not presented as no meta-analysis was performed. 

[NA] Results of bias assessment across studies are not presented as no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA] Results of additional analyses are not presented as no meta-analysis was performed. 

[Yes] "In conclusion, we think that there is no evidence in the literature about which technique (laparoscopy or inguinal approach) is preferable to repair an inguinal hernia. Probably a surgeon has to offer to the patient both techniques, and above all, considering the importance of the parental role in the decision process, the parents have to know that two different approaches exist to repair an inguinal hernia and the advantages and disadvantages of both procedures."
The conclusion summarizes the main findings and implications.

[Yes] "However, the length of follow-up in reviewed series was less for the laparoscopic approach compared with the open operation (2.3 versus 4.2 years, respectively)."
Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.

[Yes] "In summary, LH appears faster for bilateral hernia repair when compared with the inguinal crease approach. Recurrence rates appear similar, but the follow-up is less in the LH studies. Wound infection appears more likely after OH, but the incidence is small. Time to resume normal activity is similar with both approaches. Further perspective investigation, including long-term follow-up, will be needed to accurately identify the optimal approach for inguinal hernia repair in infants and children."
The conclusion provides an interpretation of the results and implications for future research.

[Yes] "No competing financial interests exist." 
The sources of funding are described.

llm_message:
P1. "[Laparoscopic versus open splenectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis]" - The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis. [Yes]

P2. "[Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.]" - The abstract provides a structured summary covering the key elements. [Yes]

P3. "[Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.]" - The introduction describes the rationale for comparing laparoscopic and open splenectomy. [Yes] 

P4. "[Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).]" - No explicit PICOS statement provided. [No]

P5. No mention of a review protocol. [No] 

P6. "[Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.]" - The eligibility criteria for studies are described. [Yes]

P7. "[Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched.]" - The search strategy is described including databases searched. [Yes]

P8. "[Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.]" - No full search strategy provided. [No]

P9. "[State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis).]" - The study selection process is described and shown in a flow diagram. [Yes]

P10. "[Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.]" - The data extraction process is described. [Yes]

P11. "[List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made.]" - The data items extracted are listed in tables. [Yes]

P12. "[Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis.]" - No risk of bias assessment described. [No]

P13. "[State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).]" - The summary measures are described. [Yes] 

P14. "[Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis.]" - Methods for meta-analysis are described including assessment of heterogeneity. [Yes]

P15. "[Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies).]" - No assessment of risk of bias across studies. [No] 

P16. "[Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified.]" - No additional analyses described. [NA]

P17. "[Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.]" - The study selection process is described and shown in a flow diagram. [Yes]

P18. "[For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations.]" - Study characteristics are presented in tables. [Yes]

P19. "[Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12).]" - No risk of bias assessment presented. [No]

P20. "[For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot.]" - Outcome data for each study are presented in tables and forest plots. [Yes]

P21. "[Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.]" - Results of the meta-analyses are presented with CIs and measures of heterogeneity. [Yes] 

P22. "[Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15).]" - No assessment of risk of bias across studies presented. [No]

P23. "[Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16]).]" - No additional analyses described. [NA]

P24. "[Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers).]" - The main findings are summarized in the discussion. [Yes]

P25. "[Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).]" - Limitations are discussed. [Yes]

P26. "[Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.]" - Conclusions are provided considering other evidence. [Yes]

P27. "[Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.]" - Sources of funding are described. [Yes]

llm_message:
Here are the relevant quotes and assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "[Yes]" 
"Open Versus Laparoscopic Inguinal Herniotomy in Children
A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Focusing on Postoperative Complications"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

P2. "[Yes]"
"Abstract: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." 
The abstract provides a structured summary.

P3. "[Yes]" 
"As one of the most frequently performed surgical procedures in infants and children, herniotomy is the standard procedure for pediatric inguinal hernia (PIH) because of its high success rate and low rate of complications."
The introduction describes the rationale in context of existing knowledge.

P4. "[Yes]"  
"The aim of this study was to compare both of the surgical strategies as regards operative time, recurrence rate, postoperative complications by means of a systematic review, and meta-analysis of the available literatures."
The objectives explicitly state the questions being addressed. 

P5. "[No]"
No protocol or registration is mentioned.

P6. "[Yes]"
"Eligibility criteria included total available studies comparing LH with OH for the repair of PIH. The children were younger than 18 years when they underwent LH or OH." 
The eligibility criteria are specified.

P7. "[Yes]"
"We systematically searched PubMed for relevant studies reported from 2005 to 2014 with the keywords “laparoscopic herniorrhaphy”, “pediatric inguinal hernia,” and “open herniorrhaphy.” Total reference lists of selected articles were also included."
The information sources are described.

P8. "[No]" 
No search strategy is presented.

P9. "[Yes]" 
"Two reviewers (S.F., Z.L.) screened the citation identified by the search strategy." 
The study selection process is described.

P10. "[No]"
The data collection process is not described. 

P11. "[Yes]"
"Details of publication (type of repairing the internal ring, trocars, and follow-up duration), inclusion and exclusion criteria, and demographics of the enrolled patients were collected and collated."
The data items are listed.

P12. "[No]"
No assessment of risk of bias is described.

P13. "[Yes]"
"Weighted mean differences and odds ratios were used for the analysis of continuous and dichotomous variables, respectively."
The summary measures are stated.

P14. "[NA]" 
Not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P15. "[NA]"
Not applicable since no assessment of bias across studies was done. 

P16. "[NA]" 
Not applicable since no additional analyses were done.

P17. "[Yes]"
"Five trials met the total inclusion criteria and had no exclusion criteria (Fig. 1): Chan et al,28 Koivusalo et al,29 Celebi et al,30 Shalaby et al,31 and Saranga et al.32"
The number of studies screened, assessed, and included is provided. 

P18. "[Yes]" 
"The 5 selected trials included 553 participants. Two hundred and seventy-eight patients received OH and 275 received LH. Study details and the quality check of total RCTs are given in Tables 1 and 2, respectively."
Study characteristics are presented.

P19. "[No]"
No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented.

P20. "[Yes]" 
"Three of the 5 trials reported the operative time for children treated with unilateral laparoscopic and open inguinal herniotomy. The pooled data showed that there was no significant difference in operative time for children treated with unilateral hernias between laparoscopic and open group with unacceptably statistical heterogeneity(I2=94%) (95% CI, −9.08 to 5.50; with 119 in the laparoscopic and 123 in the open group; Fig. 2A)." 
Results for each study are presented.

P21. "[NA]"
Not applicable since no meta-analysis was performed.

P22. "[NA]"  
Not applicable since no assessment of bias across studies was done.

P23. "[NA]"
Not applicable since no additional analyses were done. 

P24. "[Yes]"
"Our results show that LH is superior for the inguinal hernia repair in children, with shorter operative time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group as well as for bilateral hernias. Besides, less total postoperative complications was found in the LH group, especially for major postoperative complications in male children. Yet there is no significant difference regarding recurrences."
A summary of the evidence is provided.

P25. "[Yes]"  
"However, on one hand, because of the limited number of patients and studies, more RCTs need to be conducted to confirm these findings; on the other hand, the learning curve in the 5 RCTs may play an underestimated role in the study, which may weaken the results of the comparison."
Limitations are discussed.

P26. "[Yes]"
"Our results show that LH is superior for the inguinal hernia repair in children, with shorter operative time for unilateral hernias in extraperitoneal approaches group as well as for bilateral hernias. Besides, less total postoperative complications was found in the LH group, especially for major postoperative complications in male children. Yet there is no significant difference regarding recurrences."
Conclusions are provided.

P27. "[No]"
No funding sources are described.

Yet there is no significant difference regarding recurrences."
Conclusions are provided.

P27. "[No]"
No funding sources are described.

llm_message:
[Yes] "Pediatric Surgery International volume 28, pages 899–906 (2012)"
The article is identified as a systematic review in the title.

[Yes] "Abstract...background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions..." 
The abstract provides a structured summary.

[Yes] "Esophageal atresia (EA) is a relatively common congenital malformation...Improvements in prenatal diagnosis [3, 4], advances in surgery, pediatric anesthesia, neonatal intensive care and parenteral nutrition have increased the survival rate in EA in recent years to approximately 95 % [5]."
The introduction provides context about what is already known.

[Yes] "This meta-analysis aimed to investigate the complications and long-term outcome in patients with LGEA managed by DPA."  
The objectives are explicitly stated.

[No]
No review protocol or registration is mentioned.

[Yes] "Identified articles were reviewed by title, keywords and abstract by one of the authors (F.F.). All articles that did not contain original research data (e.g. letters, editorials, commentaries and reviews) and articles not giving adequate information regarding complication rates and outcome were excluded."
Study eligibility criteria are described. 

[Yes] "Common electronic databases as MEDLINE®, EMBASE®, ISI Web of ScienceSM and the Cochrane Library were searched in December 2011 using a combination of the following terms: “esophageal atresia”, “long-gap” and “delayed primary anastomosis”." 
Information sources and dates searched are described.

[Yes] "The literature search resulted in a total of 223 articles, of which 207 were identified by electronic database search and 16 by cross-referencing (Fig. 2)."
The full search strategy is presented for at least one database.

[Yes] "In total, data from 44 studies published from 1981 to 2010, were included in the quantitative synthesis." 
The study selection process is described.

[Yes] "Data extracted from each participating article included study characteristics (first author, publication year, sample size, follow-up time and mortality rate) and patient characteristics (gestational age, birth weight, type of LGEA and additional congenital anomalies)."
Data collection process is described.

[Yes] "The primary outcome of this analysis was complication rates. Anastomotic leaks, anastomotic strictures, symptomatic gastroesophageal reflux (GER), dysphagia, esophagitis, recurrent fistula, recurrent aspiration pneumonia, growth retardation and Barrett’s metaplasia were considered as complications."
Variables extracted are listed.

[No]
Risk of bias assessment for individual studies is not described.

[Yes] "incidences with a 95% confidence interval (CI) for each specific complication"
Summary measures are stated.

[NA] 
No meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is described. 

[NA]
No additional analyses are mentioned.

[Yes] "The literature search resulted in a total of 223 articles, of which 207 were identified by electronic database search and 16 by cross-referencing (Fig. 2). After removal of 117 duplicates, 106 titles, key words and abstracts were reviewed. Of these, 60 articles were excluded because after screening it emerged that these studies clearly did not meet the inclusion criteria as described. Forty-six articles met our criteria for inclusion and the full-text was examined more in detail. Of these, two articles were excluded because they referred to results of already selected articles. In total, data from 44 studies published from 1981 to 2010, were included in the quantitative synthesis."
The study selection process is described with a flow diagram.

[Yes] "The overall number of study subjects managed by DPA was 451, ranging from 1 to 74 newborns with LGEA per study. Study and patients characteristics are presented in Table 1." 
Study characteristics are presented.

[No]
No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented.

[Yes] "A cumulative meta-analysis revealed the incidences for each specific complication (Table 2)."
Results for each outcome are presented.

[NA]
No meta-analysis was performed. 

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is presented.

[NA]
No additional analyses are mentioned.

[Yes] "In conclusion, this meta-analysis shows that the DPA provides good long-term functional results. However, the high incidence of GER and associated morbidities requires early intervention to prevent ongoing feeding problems due to strictures and esophagitis. Long-term follow-up is recommended because of the potential risk of Barrett’s metaplasia."
A summary of the main findings and their relevance is provided.

[Yes] "The disadvantage of waiting for the esophageal segments to grow and hypertrophy is prolonged hospital stay and constant threat of aspiration pneumonia, which requires continuous skilled nursing supervision [21]. It may also be argued that the initial prolonged hospitalization is expensive. These factors must be balanced against reduced long-term morbidity in a child who should have a normal life expectancy and against the disadvantages of esophageal replacement."
Limitations are discussed.

[Yes] "In conclusion, this meta-analysis shows that the DPA provides good long-term functional results. However, the high incidence of GER and associated morbidities requires early intervention to prevent ongoing feeding problems due to strictures and esophagitis. Long-term follow-up is recommended because of the potential risk of Barrett’s metaplasia."
Conclusions are provided.

[No]
No statement about sources of funding is provided.

In summary, the article reports 18 out of 27 PRISMA items. The key missing elements are a review protocol, assessment of risk of bias, funding, and details on some meta-analysis items that were not applicable. Overall, the systematic review has several deficiencies in reporting based on PRISMA, but provides a helpful quantitative synthesis of DPA outcomes in LGEA patients.

llm_message:
Here are the assessments for each PRISMA item:

P1. "Long-Gap Esophageal Atresia: a Meta-Analysis of Jejunal Interposition, Colon Interposition, and Gastric Pull-Up"
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Identifies the report as a meta-analysis in the title.

P2. "Aim There is still no consensus about the optimal surgical approach for esophageal replacement in the case of long-gap esophageal atresia (LGEA) or extensive corrosive strictures." 
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Provides a structured summary in the abstract covering background, objectives, eligibility criteria, interventions, methods, results, conclusions. 

P3. "Introduction There is still no consensus about the optimal surgical approach for esophageal replacement in the case of long-gap esophageal atresia (LGEA) or extensive corrosive strictures. This is reflected in the pediatric surgical literature, which mainly consists of retrospective case series."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known in the introduction.

P4. "Aim The aim of this article was to perform a meta-analysis comparing the most widely used techniques for esophageal replacement in children: jejunal interposition (JI), colon interposition (CI), and gastric pull-up (GPU)."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Provides explicit objectives comparing interventions in the abstract.

P5. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide registration information.

P6. "Definition of Outcomes The articles were reviewed with a special focus on mortality, postoperative morbidity, and long-term follow-up. Main outcome parameters were postoperative survival rate, anastomotic complications (such as leakage and strictures recorded both postoperative and during the follow-up), and graft loss."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Specifies eligibility criteria for outcomes in the methods section.

P7. "Literature A literature search (PubMed and Embase) was performed, and all human studies published in the English-language literature between 2006 and 2011 describing esophageal replacement for LGEA were identified, using the medical subject headings “Esophageal Atresia,” “Long-gap,” “Esophagoplasty,” “Replacement,” “Interposition,” “Substitution,” “Graft,” and their combinations."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Describes literature search sources, years, and keywords. 

P8. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not provide full electronic search strategy.

P9. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not describe the study selection process.

P10. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not describe data collection or extraction process. 

P11. "Definition of Outcomes The articles were reviewed with a special focus on mortality, postoperative morbidity, and long-term follow-up. Main outcome parameters were postoperative survival rate, anastomotic complications (such as leakage and strictures recorded both postoperative and during the follow-up), and graft loss." 
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Lists variables and outcomes sought in the methods section.

P12. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not describe methods for assessing risk of bias.

P17. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not provide a flow diagram or details on study selection.

P18. "Data Collection The initial search yielded 187 potentially relevant articles, of which 172 articles were excluded because of the failure to meet the inclusion criteria. A total of 15 studies fulfilled the inclusion criteria and were analyzed in this review ([Table 1])."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Provides citations for included studies in results section. 

P19. <added-squared-brackets>[No]</added-squared-brackets> - Does not assess risk of bias within studies.

P20. "Results Data about postoperative mortality and morbidity were given in 14 studies with a total of 470 patients (264 LGEA); 344 (73%) patients underwent CI, 99 (21%) children underwent GPU, and 27 (6%) patients underwent JI."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Presents summary data for each intervention group in results section.

P21. <added-squared-brackets>[<added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>]</added-squared-brackets>

P23. <added-squared-brackets>[<added-squared-brackets>[NA]</added-squared-brackets>]</added-squared-brackets>

P24. "Conclusion Proper prospective comparative studies are lacking. GPU and CI appear comparable regarding postoperative mortality, anastomotic complications, and graft loss. On the long-term, GPU seems to be associated with a higher respiratory morbidity but fewer gastrointestinal complications than CI. Based on this article only two series provide data about JI, and they show highly divergent results. JI appears to be a valid replacement technique when performed by experienced centers; however larger numbers are needed to assess the outcomes of this procedure."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Summarizes main findings and discusses relevance in conclusion.

P25. "Discussion The present article set out to perform a meta-analysis of the literature regarding esophageal replacement for LGEA or extensive corrosive strictures. There are few prospective series, amounting to only 37 patients. Well-designed prospective comparative studies are lacking, major and minor postoperative complications are sometimes not properly defined, follow-up data are often deficient and when presented they are not homogenously described in the different studies." 
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Discusses limitations at the study and outcome level in the discussion.

P26. "Conclusion In the future, large series from these centers may offer a better insight in the results of care for this difficult patients group."
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Provides interpretation of results and implications for future research in the conclusion.

P27. "Conflict of Interest None"
<added-squared-brackets>[Yes]</added-squared-brackets> - Describes sources of funding.

llm_message:
Here are the assessments for each PRISMA item based on the provided full text:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
"Open Versus Transanal Pull-Through for Hirschsprung Disease: A Systematic Review of Long-Term Outcome"
The title identifies the publication as a systematic review. 
[Yes]

P2. Abstract: Provide a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions.  
"We performed a systematic literature review of the recent literature (2008 to 2012) including reports on long-term outcome of either OPEN surgery or L-TERPT/TERPT with a minimum follow-up period of 12 months."
The abstract describes the methods and results of a systematic literature review.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction: Describe the rationale for the review in context of what is already known.  
"Therefore, the aim of this study was to review the available data on long-term functional results in HD patients operated with conventional transabdominal pull-through (OPEN) compared with transanal approaches with and without laparoscopy (laparoscopic-assisted transanal-endorectal pull-through [L-TERPT] and transanal-endorectal pull-through [TERPT]) reported in the recent literature."  
The introduction describes the rationale for comparing long-term outcomes between open and transanal pull-through techniques.
[Yes]

P4. Objectives: Provide explicit questions addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
"[...] to review the available data on long-term functional results in HD patients operated with conventional transabdominal pull-through (OPEN) compared with transanal approaches [...]"
The objectives compare open vs transanal pull-through techniques for long-term outcomes.
[Yes] 

P5. Protocol and registration: Indicate if a protocol exists and if available, provide registration information including number.
No protocol or registration is mentioned.
[No]

P6. Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics and report characteristics used as inclusion criteria. 
"Only articles comprehensively describing the surgical methods (OPEN, L-TERPT, TERPT) and reporting on major outcome parameters (soiling/incontinence, constipation, enterocolitis, and/or stricture) were included in this study."
Inclusion criteria for study characteristics and outcomes are described.
[Yes]

P7. Information sources: Describe information sources and dates of coverage.
"A systematic PubMed search was performed to identify publications on outcome of children with HD, who underwent either OPEN, L-TERPT, or TERPT. This search was limited to the past 5 years (2008 to 2012) using the keywords “Hirschsprung” and “outcome.”"
Information sources and dates are specified.
[Yes]  

P8. Search: Present full search strategy for at least one database. 
The full search strategy for PubMed is not provided.
[No]

P9. Study selection: State process of screening, eligibility, inclusion.
"Eighteen articles finally met the inclusion criteria and were analyzed in detail." And Figure 1 shows the screening process.
The process of study screening and selection is described.
[Yes]

P10. Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction and confirmation.
"Data extracted from included articles were study characteristics (authors, journal, publication year, sample size, surgical technique, and follow-up period) and patient characteristics (age at surgery, extent of aganglionosis)."
The data extraction process is described but not confirmation.
[Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P11. Data items: List and define all variables extracted.
"Specific information on the outcome parameters constipation, enterocolitis, stricture, incontinence, and soiling were collected and analyzed."
Extracted variables related to outcomes are listed.
[Yes]

P12. Risk of bias (individual studies): Describe methods to assess risk of bias. 
No risk of bias assessment for individual studies is described.
[No]

P13. Summary measures: State principal summary measures.
"With these data, a cumulative meta-analysis was performed to compare long-term outcome of patients who underwent OPEN surgery with patients who underwent L-TERPT/TERPT surgery." And "Odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) were calculated."
Principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14. Synthesis of results: Describe methods of combining results.
"Since not all outcome parameters were reported in all articles, each specific parameter was analyzed according to the number of patients in whom that item was assessed. This enabled the calculation of the incidence of each specific outcome parameter."
The methods for synthesizing results across studies are described.
[Yes]

P15. Risk of bias across studies: Specify assessment of bias across studies.
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is described. 
[No]

P16. Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses.
No additional analyses beyond the primary synthesis are described.
[NA]

P17. Study selection: Provide numbers of studies screened, assessed, and included with reasons for exclusion, ideally with a flow diagram.
"The initial literature search resulted in a total number of 148 articles published from 2008 to 2012. Of these, 130 articles were excluded because they did not fulfill the inclusion criteria ([Fig. 1]). Eighteen articles finally met the inclusion criteria and were analyzed in detail." And Figure 1 shows the flow diagram.
The study selection process is described including flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18. Study characteristics: Present characteristics of included studies.
Table 1 shows study characteristics including sample sizes, surgical techniques, and follow-up periods.
[Yes]

P19. Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias for each study. 
No risk of bias assessment for individual studies is presented.
[No] 

P20. Results of individual studies: Present summary data and effect estimates for each study.
Results for each outcome are summarized in text and tables by surgical technique but not individually for each study.
[Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P21. Synthesis of results: Present results of meta-analyses including confidence intervals and consistency.
"Cumulative meta-analysis was performed to compare long-term outcome of patients who underwent OPEN surgery with patients who underwent L-TERPT/TERPT surgery. The latter groups were analyzed as one group due to the transanal approach in both. Odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) were calculated."
Quantitative synthesis is presented with confidence intervals but not measures of consistency.
[Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P22. Risk of bias across studies: Present results of bias assessment across studies.  
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is presented.
[No]

P23. Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses.
No additional analyses are described.
[NA]

P24. Summary of evidence: Summarize main findings including strength of evidence for each outcome.
The discussion summarizes the main findings but does not judge strength of evidence.
[Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P25. Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level and at review level.
A section describes limitations related to differences between studies and quality of studies.
[Yes]

P26. Conclusions: Provide general interpretation of results in context of other evidence. 
The conclusion provides an overall interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe funding sources and role of funders.
No information about sources of funding is provided.
[No]

[Yes] "Laparoscopic versus open orchiopexy for non-palpable undescended testes in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.

[Yes] "Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
The abstract provides a structured summary with background, objectives, methods, results, and conclusions.

[Yes] "The undescended testes (cryptorchidism) is one of the most common disorders of childhood, affecting 0.8–1.8% of infants at 1 year of age, 3% of full-term newborns, and 21% of premature babies [1, 2]." 
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about undescended testes.

[Yes] "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)."
The objectives state the explicit question being addressed regarding laparoscopic vs open orchiopexy for non-palpable testes in children.

[No] 
The methods do not indicate if a review protocol exists.

[Yes] "Eligibility criteria included all available studies comparing LO with OO for the treatment of NPT in children."
The eligibility criteria specify characteristics like interventions being compared and outcomes measured. 

[Yes] "Published studies until August 31, 2010 were searched from Medline, Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases."
The information sources describe the databases searched and date last searched.

[No]
The search strategy for at least one database is not provided.

[Yes] "After independent review, 18 publications dealing with comparison of LO and OO for the treatment of pediatric NPT were considered to be eligible for inclusion in the analysis." 
The study selection process is described including screening, eligibility, and inclusion.

[No]
The data collection process is not described. 

[Yes] "Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
The data items list the variables extracted like interventions and outcomes.

[NA]

[NA] 
No summary measures are stated since no meta-analysis was performed. 

[NA]
No synthesis methods are described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]  
No assessment of risk of bias across studies is described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[NA]
No additional analyses are described since no meta-analysis was performed.

[Yes] "Two hundred and twenty-six studies were initially found to report the laparoscopy in the management of NPT using the keywords “laparoscopy” and “non-palpable testis”. Two hundred and three were published as complete manuscripts and 23 as abstracts."
The study selection process is described including number of studies screened and excluded with reasons.

[Yes] "A summary of the studies’ methodology, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Tables 1 and 2, including 176 cases of LO and 263 cases of OO."
The study characteristics like sample sizes and interventions are presented. 

[NA] 
No assessment of risk of bias within studies is presented since no meta-analysis was performed.

[Yes] "One RCT and one OCS reported the time to resume feeding and full activity in both LO and OO [9, 14]." 
The results for outcomes considered are presented for each study.

[NA]

[NA]

[NA]

[Yes] "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the operative time, time to resume feeding and full activity is similar between LO and OO."
The discussion summarizes the main findings and considers their relevance.

[Yes] "However, due to the publishing bias, a series of RCTs are still necessary to explore the efficiencies of LO in the management of NPT in children, especially in the true outcome of orchidopexy and fertility in adulthood."
The limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.

[Yes] "Conclusions: In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the operative time, time to resume feeding and full activity is similar between LO and OO."

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of reporting quality against the PRISMA 2009 checklist for the given systematic review:

P1. "[Is] interval appendicectomy justified after successful nonoperative treatment of an appendix mass in children? A systematic review" - Identifies the report as a systematic review. [Yes]

P2. "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number." - Abstract provides background, objectives, eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, results, conclusions. [Yes] 

P3. "The purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the evidence for IA in children after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM based on the current available literature." - Describes rationale for review. [Yes]

P4. "Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS)." - No explicit PICOS statement. [No]

P5. "Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number." - No mention of protocol. [No] 

P6. "Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale." - Specifies inclusion criteria but no exclusions. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P7. "Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched." - Describes sources but no dates. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P8. "Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated." - No search strategy provided. [No]

P9. "State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)." - Describes broadening of eligibility criteria but no details on selection process. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P10. "Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators." - States data extracted independently by two reviewers. [Yes] 

P11. "List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made." - Lists outcomes extracted but no other variables. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]  

P12. "Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis." - No risk of bias assessment mentioned. [No]

P13. "State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)." - States use of binomial multilevel modeling. [Yes]

P14. "Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis." [NA]

P15. "Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)." [NA] 

P16. "Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified." [NA]

P17. "Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram." - No flow diagram or details on screening and eligibility assessment. [No] 

P18. "For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations." - Presents limited characteristics and citations for included studies. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P19. "Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)." - No risk of bias assessment. [No] 

P20. "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot." - Presents summary data and effect estimates with CIs, no forest plots. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P21. "Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency." [NA] 

P22. "Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15)." [NA]

P23. "Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16])." [NA]

P24. "Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)." - Summarizes main findings but does not discuss strength of evidence or relevance to key groups. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>] 

P25. "Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)." - Discusses limitations of included studies but not at review level. [Partial <added>[Yes]</added>]

P26. "Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research." - Provides interpretation and implications for future research. [Yes]

P27. "Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review." - No mention of funding or support. [No]
